Head: beige colored foam. Color: clear, copper. Aroma: laurel. Taste: laurel, glue?, bitter. Palate: dry, light CO2, medium body, bitter finish. Overall: not one of the best.
Dark brown with small head. Taste and aroma of raisins, candy sugar and malts.

Poured from a refrigerated bottle into a lager glass. Pours a dark brown with a suitable head of khaki colored foam. Aroma has some caramel and cola aspects to it with maybe a little bit of toffee. Taste is bready and semi-sweet with a touch of bitterness noticeable in the finish. Overall, its no Celebrator, but it isnt too bad, either.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle. Dark pour, white head. Very complex aroma and taste of fruit, fig, and caramel. Very nice.
Aroma of malts, caramel, spices and some ripe fruits. Flavor of caramel malts, plums, spices, yeast and some fruits.
Pours a clear red-brown with a 1-finger cream head.  Smells of caramel, chocolate, hay.  Taste is sweet and bitter, hints of fruit, very malty.

"And zis Doktor Jhones, iz how ve say goodbye in chGermany!" The aroma is everything the descriptor says it is - a sweet, malty punch in the nose. I would say it has a flat cola appearance. Hazy brown but not too dark. Tastes of dark fruit and even some smoke. Palate feel is almost gritty. Really grinds from start to finish, and in pretty much he same fashion throughout. Recommended fr doppel fans. Sessioners beware.

01/06/2012 Birrifugio Trastevere (tap). Bruna, riflessi color coca cola, abbastanza densa e lievemente torbida, schiuma bianco-sporca non molto abbondante e non molto persistente. Al naso sentori di malto, caramello, pane, zucchero di canna, con note tostate. In bocca è dolce, caramellata, zuccherosa, toffee, liquirizia nel finale. Corpo medio, carbonazione corretta. Alla lunga risulta stucchevole come molte doppeldock, ma nel complesso non è male.

Complex sweet and dark fruit aroma. Brown with amber highlights throughout and taupe head. Layers of dark fruit, caramel and malt. Toasty as well and has a velvety coat over the tongue. Booze is present in mid-palate.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, thanks Aaron! Dark brownish black pour with off white head, aroma has notes of deep dark fruits, caramel toffee, hints of roast, slight chocolate and coffee, hints of slight earth notes as well.  Taste is a nice mix of dark fruits, toffee, hints of biscuit, molasses, some slight yeast, finishing fairly sweet.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2012 Tap @ Huber Haus Omaha. Pours a clear dark orangish brown appearance with a fluffy, tan head. Lots of sweet notes in the aroma including caramel, raisin, fig, port, and black cherries. Toasty dark caramel malty, chocolate, dark fruity, raisin, plum flavor with a lingering caramel, syrupy sweetness. Maybe a little too sweet for me but still tasty.

Smells of figs and raisens..  No head.  Tastes like figs, and very dark caramel...almost tastes like earthy candies.  Very dark brown, but not quite black.  Flavor hides alcohol content amazingly.  This is a solid beer.

The aroma is awesome! It has a port taste with hints of chocolate. Maybe one of the best aromas. Pours like ice tea with a bubbly head but rises eventually. The palate is very smooth and silky. Hate flavor is very complex.

On tap at the Malt House.  Really look at the commercial description and it is spot on.  I did not know anything about this one when I had it, but I loved the dark fruits blended with the  toffee on this one.  VERY nice surprise on this brew.

On tap at the Malt House - Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Nose is big fruity yeast with plums, raisins, and sweet honey bread sweetness. Taste is big sweet bread right away, then a blast of big dark fruit, transitioning into a honey/candi sugar sweetness. Big body with smooth carbonation. Wow...this was not what I was expecting with the fruitiness, but it was intriguing and a fun experience. Good stuff.

Low carbonation quickly dissipating head deep reddish brown color notes of fig date prune breast malty profile alcohol well hidden a very nice doppel bock 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Smells like raisins to me.  Amber-brown in color with an off-white head that settles.  Sweet up front, raisiny, bready-malty in the middle with a nice hoppy-bitter finish.

On tap. Pours deep brown with a small light tan head. Aroma is very strong nutty, dark fruits, light roast, super malty, toffee. Flavor is much the same, so rich and malty all around, tons of that bready nutty character, lots of that dark fruit cake character, into a sweet and pound cake finish, very rich and a touch of cocoa. Medium full to full body and a soft carbonation. Good stuff
Pours a black color.  Got this one on draught at maxs as well.  Smells of many different fruits and a little whiskey!  A bit sweet.  Good.

Dark, sweet, with interesting notes of raisin and slight roasted grain tones. Reminds me of a dark, strong Belgian ale in the malt complexity, although heavier. Overall and good dark, malty, lager, but probably a bit too sweet for anything but very occasional drinking.

Bottle, poured deep brown with a minimal tan head. Complex aroma.  Tasted figs, malt coffee and a hint of licorice.  Overall a good beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown color with an off-white creamy head.  Aroma of fig, raisin, cherry, toffee, and hint of port.  Lots of fig and cherry flavor with toffee, raisin, and caramel supporting.  Thick creamy body. Really nice beer.

(bottle).  Deep mahogany complexion with minimal head. Flavors are sweet, very rich dried fruits like raisin, fig & prune.  The palate is very smooth.  Complex and enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours deep brown with a small tan head, little retention/lace. Aroma of molasses, dark fruit (fig, raisin, cherry), toffee, nuts. Taste is quite sweet, rich toffee/nutty taste with raisin and licorice notes. Palate is thick, sticky, soft carbonation, sweet finish.
Translucent brown with a tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit and brown sugar.  Taste is very sweet, rich fig malt with a caramel and anise finish.  9% well hidden.  Top-tier dopplebock.

2 year Bottle pours brown black with no head. Smell is big, chocolate and licorice. Taste is full and smooth chocolate malt with lots of smaller flavors. There is a dark fruit, cherries, and dates, some licorice and minimal cognac flavor. This is maybe my favorite doppelbock.

50 cl bottle @ Salhojankadun Pub, Tampere.
Originally rated on 20090501.
Pours clear dark copper colour with medium head. Aroma of sweetish caramel malts, ripe fryuits, earth notes, mild liquorice and grain. Flavour of caramel, plum, mild ripe fruits, sugar candy and some bread. Balanced and smooth.
5325

50 cl bottle (7% ABV) @ Salhojankadun Pub
Aroma is sweet and malty with toffee andc some roastiness. Also hints of butter. Flavour is rewlly malty with sweet toffee and some coffee. Clean and flawless DP.

Aroma of caramel malt, milk chocolate and some dark fruit. Appearance is dark cola brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose, but with a light, herbal finish. Palate was bubbly with a medium mouthfeel. Among the German Doppelbocks I have tried; it was average.

500ml bottle in a stem glass.  Pours deep brown/ruby with a lacy, cream-colored head.  Aroma of roasted malts, dark fruits, chocolate, and some light hops.  Flavor really strong of the malts.  Thicker than most beers of this style.  A really good German beer.

Extremely dark brown pour with a thin white head. Massive dark fruit and dark sugar in this beer. Raisin, fig, plum, caramel, molasses, brown sugar, and cherry. Thick rich palate with carbonation slightly on the low side. Really yummy

Pours a dark brown with a quickly diminishing brownish head. Aroma is licorice, toffee, sugar, fruit, and a few other fine things. In short, it smells pretty damn good ad bockish. Taste is kind of heavy, especially towards the finish and the aftertaste when this beer gets pretty intense. Some feel akin to astringency happens at the finish and I cant quite tell why. Lots of roasted malts. Sweet, but not cloying. Kind of on the thick side of things. This is a good, perhaps a great, doppelbock, but compared to the incredible Weltenberger I had yesterday, this is a step down.
Clear copper with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit and nutty. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish. Full bodied. Soft and smooth. 101211

Bottle from michael-pollack.  Licorice and molasses seem to stand out in the aroma with also whiffs of caramel, brown sugar, and cardboard.  Dark brown color; some amber tint in there, with a thin tan head that struggles fully develop.  A touch roast to the flavor with also a bit of unpleasant metal.  This is pretty sweet with a lot of that seemingly coming from caramel and toffee.  Dark fruit (thinking tart plums), cherry fruitcake, yeast, and molasses mix in but arent enough to prevent the sweet flavors from being somewhat distracting.  Perhaps those flavors in itself are also sweet.  This tastes kind of barleywine-like.  I didnt stay with it too long as it just wasnt doing it for me.

500ml bottle poured almost black in color with a modest beige head and some very nice lacing.  Aroma is dark roasted malts and chocolate.  Taste is malty sweetness with some chocolate and a mildy hoppy bitter finish.  A very well done doppelbock with a medium to heavy body and mild carbonation and a nice balance of flavors.  Highly recommended for a tasting experience.

Pours a dark amber-brown color with a small khaki head. Aromas of chocolate and dark fruit. Flavors of chocolate, toffee, caramel, fig and vanilla with a very slight presence of alcohol. Creamy mouthfeel with a rich caramel sweetness. An impressive Doppelbock...........one of the best Ive had.

Pours deep brown...nearly black...with a thin tan head.  Aroma is sweet and roasty with notes of fig, vanilla, coffee...slightly winey.  Flavor is slightly more fruity with raisin and cherry...still fig, vanilla and coffee...spicy and earthy to cut down the wineyness in the flavor.  Mouthfeel is silky and thick with a warming, lingering earthy/roasty finish.  Nice!
Inköpt av Ulfs mamma till ölprovning av tysk öl. Blev nästan kvällens favorit. Ett stort öl med massor av söta smakreferenser men ändå med bra balans.

Poured a clear dark brown with a thin light-tan head.  Nice sweet aroma with grapes, raisins, and caramel malts.  Some alcohol noticeable.  Taste is smooth and with lots of caramel malts.  Some raisins and plumbs too.  Finish is a little flat, my bottle might not have been carbonated well enough.  Some earthy doughy notes in the finish.  Overall pretty good, but a little too syrupy for me.

Bottle from the brewery shop in Ettal, bought 14-Aug-11 but still labelled as 7% - old stock? Poured a deep red with very little head, old wine and some molasses on the nose, dry and chewy with peppery hops, some dried dark fruit, a little liquorice and clove, and a dry-bitter aftertaste with a very faintly musty tang.
500 ml bottle from Premier Gourmet.  Pours thick, deep brown, slightly cloudy.  Big sweet malt aroma and taste, slightest hint of the 9% alcohol.  Very good doppelbock!
Great dopplebock that poured a very dark color with a roast aroma and a little bit of carmel. Nice smooth taste of various roasted malts and candies with a good alcohol kick.
Bottle, 7% ABVDark chestnut color, small head. It has a light caramel aroma and a good caramel flavor, with respectable sugars, and a light nutty touch. Correct bitterness. Pleasant.
(bottle) medium brown with almost no head. Sweet malt aroma. Flavor is syrupy sweet malt, some caramel and dark fruits, alcohol.
Bottle thanks to Seth.  Wow, what an impressive doppelbock!!  All kinds of sweet caramel malt upfront with background flavors of dark fruits and chocolate.  Really impressive...

Dezent herber, eher zurückhaltender Antrunk und weiteres Aroma. Alkoholisch, gleichzeitig aber auch wässrig, das Malz ist laff, ebenso das Getreide. Zum Ende scharf alkoholisch. Wo bleibt die Würzigkeit? 10/7/7/8/13/7

500 mL bottle. Pours brown with a medium white head. Aroma is very malty, sugar/caramel, bread and yeast, dark fruit. Flavor follows along, sweet but not cloyingly so, a nice malt base.  Very nice doppelbock.

Deep Mahogany with a tan head, looks like a flat soda... Sweet, but not sticky, raisin, fig, prune, lots of dried fruits... Choc roasty, raisin, fig, nice flavor, little sweet but not overly like a lot of big doppelbocks can be... lively, medium body, sweet sticky mouthfeel, does finish sweet...

This was the 9% ABV. The pour is a deep mahogany brown with a fairly nice head that settles to a foamy ring. The aromas are amazingly versatile with figs, molasses, licorice, toffee, and dark fruits. It comes with an excellent body.  The taste is both sharply bitter and molasses sweet.  It gels together in fine fashion.
Pours dark brown with a low head. Aroma is sweet malts. Flavor is way too sweet malts with some alcohol and fruits. Hard to finish.

Bottle picked up at Chevy Chase in DC. Served in a Captain Lawrence tulip.

Pours a moderate brown color that is pretty transparent. Thin tan head forms and then falls away very quickly. The nose has a bit of chocolate and mild malt sweetness. Pretty plain. Mild dark fruits in the background. The flavor is really plain and the mouthfeel is fairly watery for a beer of this style and strength. Mild malt sweetness and a touch of caramel. Really bland and disappointing. Moderate carbonation on a too-light body. Not a very good example of the style.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-21-2011

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2012 Aroma of dark fruits, raisins especially.  appearance is deep brown with a small creamy head.  tastes of figs, toffee and roast chestnuts. finishes with more of the roasted sugars.  delicious doppelbock.

Botte, thanks to ughsmash in trade, dark walnut color with short off white foam, aroma is strong pumpernickel bread and caramel, flavor of co.wboy coffee, caramel toffees, dark bread and cashew, finish is not too thin

0.5L 7% version, almost no head, clear and very very dark red bordering on the brown, maybe the consequence of some oxidation, aoma of nuts, caramel and some dried fruits, flavour of caramel and dark fruits, extremely smooth with a body a tad light, long mellow bittersweet aftertaste. Very good sipping dopplebock.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2011 The beer pours a medium brown with a light tan head, good retention and lacing...light aroma of caramel with a dirty sock finish... taste is toasted caramel with a chalk finish, pretty bland here... pass
Sample from bottle. Very darl brown with off-white head. Caramel and nutty aroma. Sweet with some fruity and roasted malt in taste.

50cl bottle @Punainen Ahven, Helsinki. Poured mahogany color, thin head. Aroma is caramel and toffee with some dark fruits, flavor is toffee, strong malty and smooth. Easy to drink for this high alc%. Alcohol is not showing.
Very thick, a little bit of coffee in it gives it a hint at a schwarzbier, a very good doppelbock, although not very easy to find.

Comes in a nicely decorated reused 1 pint .9 ounce bottle. Brewed according to is historic recipe of 1609, created by the Benedictine Monks. This is the U.S. import version.

Pours a nice dark brown with hints of burnt golden orange. A small tan head forms and quickly dissipates with a vigorous pour.

The smell is the smooth, sweet chocolate malt of dopplebock weve come to know and love. Some dark dried fruit in there as well. Also a slight nuttiness. One of the better smelling doppelbocks.

Mouthfeel is smooth with a small amount of carbonation. Taste is of fruits, cocoa, coffee, and hops. Alcohol is present with a bit of burn in the throat. Like others have stated the word "juicy" comes to mind, not in the fruit juice sense but in the overall feel and scent of this masterfully crafted brew.

For doppelbocks it is pretty high up there, a solid one for this category. I am itching to try the German version as it has less abv.
Has a definite black currant flavor to the nose and the palate. Beautiful taste notes. One to recommend.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2011 Aroma burnt caramel, that is continued in the toasted chocolate taste. That said, this isnt my favorite style, so the burnt finish made me visibly twitchy with a bitter beer face, which is reflected in my score.

0.5 l bottle (7.2 %) at Old Bricks Inn, Jyväskylä. Dark amber to brown color. The aromas and flavors of bready maltiness, soft higher alcohols, toffee, raisiny caramel and hint of herbal hops. Sweet taste. Full body. Very typical firmly malty bock.
Bottle. Pours black with white head. Nose of fig, toffee, grain, caramel malt and toffee. Taste of barley, fig, caramel malt, grain and toffee. Medium body.

Looks non-too-impressive from the pour - almost like a pepsi, but with some minimal head and a more opaque body.  Aroma is sweet and heavenly but subtle - caramel, prune, alcohol.  Taste is sweet but with a bit of alcohol and bitterness striking oddly on the back of the tongue.  Leaves a nice complex taste all around the mouth to savor.  Palate is quite full, smooth and extremely wet - almost like a milkshake, okay not thaaat thick.  Overall, a really lovely doppelbock - my favorite style!  I could drink this anywhere, anytime and be happy as a clam.

Bottle that Lozs sister and brother in law (Jude & Baz) very kindly picked up from the brewery for me on a recent holiday nearby, consumed 27.01.11.   Pours dark brown good clarity good looker. Taste is cocoa, flat coca cola, coffee, raisins and sticky fruit, some dates, liquorice, sasparilla its just wonderful, gorgeous flavours. Aroma maybe not quite so brill but good with loads of malt and dark fruits. Really loved this beer, big thanks to Jude & Baz. Wish they could have stuck a case of this in their luggage.  A7 A5 T9 P4 Ov16  4.1

1/8/10.  On tap - a special 10.5% version with big thanks to Steve from Kickbacks for hooking me up!  Huge vanilla and burnt caramel in there with hints of lingering chocolate.  Cant tell its 10% at all.
From a bomber (9%). Pours thin medium brown with a lightly carbonated head.  Roast, a little chocolate, and complex malts dominate this doppelbock.

Pours a dark and clear reddish brown. Almost no head, maybe a titch flat. The aroma is a beautiful blend of chocolate and dark fruits.Taste is rich and smooth with high quality malt, fruit, and mollasses. A VERY well done doppelbock. Thumbs way up....

Bottle pours dark cola color with brief off-white head.  Aroma malts and caramel.  Taste sweet malts. caramel with a slightly bitter hop finish.  Medium palate, slightly carbonated.  Alcohol disguised.

Sweet malty doppelbock, pretty good.

At the Doppelbock Width Tasting in Shachars house, thanks Shachar, bottle, pours murky brown and little rusty with a small head, apple and sweetish aroma, sweet flavor, sweetish ending, and overall a tasteful beer.

A: The pour is a dark brown/cola colored elixir with a small off-white head.

S: A nice fruity sweetness to start things off. I get plums, figs, cherries, and raisins. Theres some caramel maltiness as well as a hint of toasted bread and cola.

T: The flavor is much the same, perhaps a bit more "bread forward". Lots of sweet cola and caramel along with very ripe dark fruit flavors.

M: The body is medium with a lively carbonation that fills the mouth nicely.

D: I love me a good doppelbock and this one certainly fit. Definitely worth a tick.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a good amount of head.  Malty flavor with a quick finish.
Draft. Pours amber brown with an off white head. Sweet malty aroma with some light roasty and toasty notes. The flavor has caramel, molasses, toffee, and light roasted malts. Nice.

This was the only beer from Ettaler I was willing to try from the Binnys in Lincoln Park, Chicago. It was sitting on the top shelf in the warm section, exposed to ultra-bright fluorescent light and some of the labels on the other bottles showed signs of age and rough handling. That being said, the pour produced a crystal clear deep mahogany colour with a soapy beige head that I could only get to form with the most vigorous of pours. The nose, below some mineral notes (aluminum and iron), has some surprisingly pleasant aromas (given the condition of the bottle and improper storage) of black cherry, fig, rich caramel, toffee, a whisper of anise and faint chocolate. The flavour, while slightly skunked, still has a lot going for it. As it warms, full flavours of fig, cherry, cola, caramel, tobacco, licorice  and noble hops. The palate is chewy up front, slick in the finish, and the carbonation could use a little more psi and some finer bubbles. I will be in Munich in a month, so Ill re-rate then. Wanted to get this in the States to really see what the trip overseas and a third of the way across the country does to a beer. Oh yea, and the Reinheitsgebot is dumb.

Serving: 500 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors. 
Aroma: The nose is a little skunky with some light roasted notes and a malt undercurrent. 
Appearance: It pours a ruddy brown with a sizeable foamy, light tan head.  Good head retention. 
Taste: Very malty with a twinge of a metallic note.  That note flows in and out amidst dark caramel, raisin, and pumpernickel notes. 
Palate: Medium to rich in body with a coating mouthfeel, lower carbonation, and a lingering raisin and dark malt finish. 
Overall: I can do without the metallic note, but this is a nice winter brew.  Rich and filling, its not one to session per se but to enjoy slowly.

Where to start this brew is complex to say the least .... Pours a deep mahogany with a ruby tint and creamy light tan head ... decent lacing ... aroma of dark fruits figs, raisins, cherry and caramel ..... taste of sweet fruits like cherries and grapes with darker fruits figs and raisins .... caramel and molasses give it a thick character with a slight roasted finish .... kinda warm finish and its definitely a session beer with 9% snuck up on me ... a big beer lots of flavor

At a tasting, thanks Shahar, pours dark rusty with a small head, aroma of plums, dates, raisins, honey, cinnamon and wood, flavor of bread, biscuits, cognac, grapes, pretty zesty with a moderate bitterness, medium to full body.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks Shachar. Clear copper-deep amber color. Aroma of malt, caramel, honey, some nutty hints and light toastiness. Sweet malty flavor with caramel, hints of toasted bread and light herbal notes. Medium-bodied. A nice delicate Doppelbock.

Bottle: Pours a Dark Amber/Brown - with a moderate off white head. I was surprised to smell chocolate immediately, as well as raisin, taste is sweet with a bit of alcoholic bitterness, medium body and chewy feel, flavors are caramel malt, chocolate raisins, coffee - I was pleasantly surprised by this one!

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 1 pint .9oz bottle into a dimpled mug. The abv is listed at 9% and there is no freshness date.

Appearance: It has a dark brown, almost black body with deep reddish highlights. On top it has a small one finger tall tan head which quickly fades to a ring of foam around the edge of with a thin film covering. Buy the end there was no head at all and lacing was nil.

Smell: Deep malty sweetness dominates the nose. There are hints of burnt caramel, dark brown sugar and herbal earthy hops.

Taste/Palate: It has a firm full body with a heavy slick texture and light carbonation. This gives it a coating effect with its deep rich malty sweetness. For me it seems a bit too sweet but complex as well. It has notes of deep caramelized sugar, bread crust, light toast, brown sugar, raison and lots of prune notes. It finishes with lots of residual sweetness then a short herbal/leafy/earthy bitterness which struggles to add some sense of balance.

Notes: For me it was a bit on the sweet side and yet it full of complexity which I do like.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are fruits, syrop, malt, hops and notes of licorice.

Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. Some caramellic notes. Moderate bitter caramellic flavor. Some alcoholic notes. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate.

On tap at the Publick House in Boston.  Cloudy brown colour with foamy off white head and nice lacing. Nice aroma of sweet malty molasses.  Malty sweet flavour of dried fruit, figs and alcohol, with medium carbonation. Balanced aftertaste. Alcohol noticeable but not overpowering. Nice lingering aftertaste.
reddish purple body. aroma of plum, yeast, caramel and dough. flavor is primarily of raison, alcohol and sugar. finishes slightly cloying, yet appetizing

Bottle from Monument Wine. Pours mahogany with a thin tan head and a rich chocolate and coffee aroma. The flavor is roasted malt with coffee, toffee, dark fruit and lots of licorice. This is perhaps the most complex German beer I have sampled. Mmm Good.

Mmmmm mm! Gooood beer! Poured a beautiful huge tan foamy frothy textured head and lots of lace. Color is a rich ruby tinged mahogoney. Aroma is malty and dark ripe fruit. Flavors that and a lot more: pick out figs, dates, plums, prunes, raisins, sweet cherries, a little pear, lots of malt, a little roasty, and booze at the end. Body is very good as is the carbonation. Almost a session, but ya better be careful.

Pours a hazy deep amber brown with a low golden head. aroma is crazy: molasses and figs, mince meat pie, bread crusts, rum & raisin ice cream all come to mind. I could smell this for hours! Flavours do not disappoint either: chewy dark caramel, burnt sugar (the top of a creme brulee), brown bread crusts, fig paste, raisins, sponge toffee. Sticky sweet and delicious!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Draft at Birreria Paradiso.  Brown-black opaque.  Sweet true German malt tones, brown sugary.  Yeasty and rich.  Seemed bigger to me, this might have been the first time I had the 9% version.  Pungent, funky, Doppelbock aroma.  Good.
Great coffee caramel flavor. Brown color with white head. Malty finish with creamy texture on the palate.

bottle - Pours dark brown with a lingering one finger head.  It has a rich malt aroma with dark fruit and caramel.  This brew tastes very sweet with a thick body and fruity caramel flavors.  Its quite tasty though to me it was a little too overpoweringly sweet even for the style.  Still, its a quality brew.

16.9 oz bottle pours a murky tobacco brown with minimal retaining off white head into a stem glass; nice lacing.  Aroma of molasses, black and red licorice, purple grapes milk chocolate, caramel.  Exceptional nose.  Well malted profile very similar to the nose: molasses and milk chocolate blend into earthy notes with black licorice, finishing with caramel, roasted malt, and red licorice.  Medium bodied with a velvety mouthfeel and low-medium carbonation level.  Flavors are deep and well balanced.  Truly a desert in a glass, Ettaler Curator does not disappoint.  Fantastic brew.

Very dark brown, thin tan head that settles quickly to leave big bubble lacing.  Aroma of burnt toast, dates and plums.  Taste has plenty of dark fruits and roasted malts.  Complex and interesting, full bodied.
Draft at Redlight. Pours a nice reddish brown pour. Sour roasted grain, toffee aroma. Toffee, roasted malt taste. Well balanced and tasty, awesome brew.

16.9 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour was a deep walnut stain with two fingers of off-white head sitting on top.  Nose is burnt caramel, molasses, raisins, malt, metal, and cold stone.  Taste is burnt caramel, raisins, malt, and figs, with a deep lingering caramel finish.  This brew is fantastic!  I enjoyed this one more then the famed celebrator, which Ive heard is a top choice for the style.  While the nose wasnt my favorite for this style, that taste was extremely complex.

Draft @ redlight redlight. A gorgeous chestnut body with some nice lacing on the glass. Nose of raisins and prunes with a big malty melanoidin body. Super drinkable for such a big beer. Slightly drying from the alcohol, with a rich plum and caramel malt flavor, some notes of burnt caramel. Lush body.

Bottle from the store across the Ettaler monastery. Pours a dark amber. Mild head. Malty, deep flavor. Aroma is of hops, toffee. Hints of chocolate, bitterness at the end.  Thin body. Dry finish. Warms the stomach.

(Bottle at Janoinen Lohi) Poured very deep reddish brown and clear with medium sized, quick and white head. Aroma contained lot of malts and some roastedness. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, molasses, roastedness, sweetness, hint of grass, light saltiness, chocolate and pleasant bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and sweet. Very balanced, good tasting and easily drinkable doppelbock.

draft at redlight redlight in Orlando, pours hazy brown with a medium dark tan head.  Dark red fruit and spice nose with notes of coffee and biscuity malt.  Flavor is very robust and rich with chocolate malt and maple syrup, not too sweet though, the finish is spicy and lingering.  Thanks to George for suprising me with this one.
Draft at redlight redlight.  Caramel, roast and a touch of rye inthe aroma and flavor.  Very good dopplebock with a finish that lingers.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Rich caramel, toffee, and figs on the nose, raisins and molasses.  Pours a rich reddish amber with a thin white head.  Rich caramelly malts, figs, hints of smoke, toffee with traces of roastiness.  Very good dopplebock!

Glass bottle

Picked up at Binnys in downtown Chicago I was looking forward to this.  Unfortunately I found it somewhat disappointing.  Whether it was a bit past its prime or my palate was not in the mood something did not concur with the opinion of many previous raters.  I think I may buy this again when I am in the mood for a run of doppelbocks and compare it to some others on the market.

Aroma / Appearance - Short lived and cascading downwards into the glass I observed a wonderful flow of reddish brown semi-opaque in character.  Chocolate dipped cherry pits, figs, malts, and something stale give it life.  Sourdough bread and red wine gave it a nice depth.  The total experience was solid but somehow less than what I was expecting at the time.

Flavor / Palate - Raisin bread, bitter chocolate, and warm muffins kick the palate awake.  Very dark and rich it might have been a bit too much at the time.  The letdown was the dry finish which lacked anything complex.  Ultimately this was not a terrible beer and revisiting it has me questioning my original feelings but unless this makes it to Ohio I will have to wait a while.

2009 Bottle - Pours clear dk brown with a small beige head...aroma is rich dark fruit and malt, caramel, toffee, dough, roast...flavour follows closely, raisin and fig, plum, yeast, roast grain...a bit of heat in the back, but pretty damn tasty...this was a nice surprise...

Location: .5 liter bottle from State Line, 10/25/09


Aroma: A complex aroma that includes berries, fig, toffee, caramel, coffee, raisin, bread, roasted malts, licorice, and more.  

Appearance: A nice brown color with a slight red hue, a thin tan head, and no lace.

Flavor: Flavor is quite similar to the nose in both complexity and make-up; however, I do note an increase in licorice and less fruitiness.  Still, the flavor is quite complex with an interesting mixture of sweet, malty flavors.

Palate: Medium in body and quite low in carbonation, this beer has a decent, though not outstanding mouthfeel

Overall Impression:
Really quite an interesting beer.  What a first impression it gives when you open it up and get a whiff.  Its hard to oversell the wonderful complexity of the nose on this one.  I really thought it was quite interesting, almost reminded me of a nice Belgian quad in that you just dont usually see a level of complexity like this one in many other styles.  I would definitely recommend trying this one out.

Sample at Coles German Tasting 2009. Brown chestnut pour with reddish hues. Dark dried fruit aroma, raisins, sweet malts,burnt coffee in the aroma. Dried fruits, burnt coffee, some wierd maltiness up front. Fuller mouthfeel. decent

Clear ruby brown color with a fleeting tan head.  Nice aromas of yeasty dark raison bread mild coffee and molasses. Smooth medium body. Hearty flavors of  toasted heavy yeasty raison bread earthy molasses, fruit cake sweet spices. Great Bock.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Deep browned chestnut appearance with dense, off-white cream head. The initial whiff is redolent of a Baltic Porter with raisin and caramel at the forefront giving way to a see of melanoidin malt, molasses, toffee, and licorice--as advertised. Flavor is rich with melanoidin and raisin. Deep, dried, candied frutis penetrate the palate. The sweet, caramelized flavors never  quite become cloying and there is a hint of nondescript bitterness at the back-end to balance it. Marsala notes waft off the glass as the beer warms and airates. Puissant alcohol plum and chocolate cherry raisin pack a final wallop. An exquisite dessert brew or fireside sipper for those frigid months,
Bottled. Poured dark dark brown. Raisiny nutty aroma, smallish head. Nice, dark and delicious. Alcohol wasnt overpowering.

Malty aroma of rich molasses with walnuts also present. Brown with a medium tan head, no lacing. Appropriate body. It tastes mainly of sweet molasses with walnut and wood notes preventing it from becoming too sweet. Alcohol is noticeable but downplayed a bit. A faint light woodiness lingers. Works well with a Virginia ham or a well seasoned tenderloin.
Pours a light tan head with an amber body.  Smells of molasses and malt.  Flavor is molasses, bready, toast, some hops, and clove.

I am surprised that I havent rated this yet. 500 mL bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a deep ruby red color with a thin head. Fair head retention and lacing. Aroma is sweet malts, toffee, raisins, light anise. Taste is anise, alcohol, toffee, dark fruits including primarily raisin. Full bodied with significant alcohol warmth. Very tasty. Good doppelbock.
Bottle that was a bonus of some kind.  Pours brownish with a tan head.  Nose is sweet and quite rich.  Taste is very full bodied and very rich with a lot of licorice.

Sampled in Fussen. A really good and really strong brew, especially after a few wimpy Pilsners and Hefes. A really strong doppelback that packs a big malty punch. Full of lots of different flavors from fruits and coffee. A good brew, but has a big aftertaste that takes a bit of getting used to.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2009 Bottle from A Southern Season (though I also got one as an extra from one of my trading buds... thanks!).  Pours dark chestnut with just a bit of light coming through around the edges.  Not a big head, but a tenacious beige ring throughout.  Lovely dark fruity nose... toffee, dark caramel, dried dark fruits, raisins, port, some anise and soy.  Some creaminess as well.  Big think palate, but not quite syrupy.  Really quite good.

Clear dark brown color...Small off white head...Malty sweet aroma of toffee and caramel...Full body, creamy mouthfeel with a hint of carbonation...Like drinking a meal...Fruity sweetness with a bit of roastiness in the finish...A perfect 5 star doppelbock...
pours brown with a beige head.  very smooth and sweet.  creamy, tastes like candy.
Brown pour with a foamy tan head. Caramel and ripe fruit aroma. Sweet tea-like taste with roast and caramel. Good thick and creamy body.

Bottle  Pours a clear brown with a small off white head.  The head has average staying power.  The aroma is of hay, caramel, toffee, licorice, figs, and coffee.  A very complex aroma.  You could sniff this one for hours and never stop finding new smells.  Has a light carbonation.  A good mouthfeel.  The flavor is like the aroma keeps changing on your tongue.  Has a good blending.  This one has a thick syrupy texture.  Has a full body.  A good finish with everchanging aftertastes.  This is tasty.

Bottle. Heavy malt smells of dark bread, toasted and molasses, light herbs and meat for the hops and yeast, with background notes of Worcestershire sauce, raisin, cola and spices. Head is small, frothy, off-white with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightly acidic to start, then finishes moderately sweet and slightly bitter. Palate is medium, creamy and has a soft carbonation. A good Doppelbock, full and rich, but just a touch too sweet.

Bottle from Monument in Concord, CA. Pours a dark orange/copper/amber. With a beige head. Aroma is a veggie dark malt. Full bodied with creamy carbonation. Flavor is all over the place. Roasted caramel. Herb. Hop. Treacle. Anise. God knows what. Heavy duty but not sticky sweetness. Theres a lot of dark fruit. Dang good beer. Waited years for this, and it was worth it.

(bottle) pours a clear ruby-brown colour with a thin off-white head. aroma of bread, toasted grain, light dark fruits and marshmallow. flavour is the same, with some alcohol and a long roasted-bitter finish. full-bodied with medium carbonation.

Bottle: Brown auburn with a wispy tan head (good retention considering the ABV). Sweet malt aroma- brown sugar, maple, mild toasted notes. Slick and warming body. Very sweet flavor- maple, raisiny notes with light toast. Peppery nondescript bitterness is on the back, but it isnt cohesive with the big malty body. Too sweet and lacking nuance, in my humble opinion.

Dark brown pour with minimal head. Sweet, dark fruit aroma. Very sweet. As it warms, it develops more complexity. Figs, prunes, licorince, toffee and caramel. Also, chocolate covered raisins. The sweetness gets more tolerable after sipping it for a while. Pretty nice doppel.
500ml bottle. Dark amber/brown pour. Sweet malt and dark fruit. Sweet, a little bitter, some toffee and more dark fruits, very tasty doppelbock.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 16.9 oz bottle, via EDA.  Pours a dark chestnut brown body with just a small off-white head that quickly faded to a wispy film.  The nose is roasty and a bit grainy with maybe a touch of oxidation creeping in.    A hint of smoke, dark fruits and husky grains as well.  The flavor is a little sweeter than I like for my Doppelbocks.  Some almost brown sugar like sweetness that makes me think of sticky buns.  Coffee, roast, plum, a touch of leather, a sight alcohol kick on the back end, and a lingering sweet burnt caramel finish.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with a bit of stickiness and moderate fizzy carbonation. This was alright, but after having a bottle of Weihenstephaner Korbinian directly before it, this paled in comparison.
Bottle:  Dark brown colored pour with medium sized head.  Fruity, malty, bready aroma.  Roasted malts, caramely finish.
Bottle 0,50ltr: Dark brown coloured Doppelbock from the south of Bavaria. This brew is one of the better i drunk in this style. Very dried fruity taste and some caramel.

Taste 2/9 Bottle. Looks: Deep brown body with a one inch foam that disappears to a rim job. Aroma: Rich hay and grain with dark fruit. Taste: A very full flavor of figs, licorice and some darker roast malts. Almost sweet but the sourness, yeast and spice keep it under control. Quite good.

Bottle pours medium brown with little carbonation and head.  Sweet malts in the aroma.  A bit of figs in there too.  Maybe even molasses.  Slightly sticky body.  Alcohol is very present in this one.  Worth another try.

What a perfect doppelbock.  This thing is perfectly balanced with the light burnt notes setting off the light malt sweetness to tremendous effect.  The effect is a very soft beer, which never makes a mistake in any direction (alcohol, burntness, pruniness, sweetness).  It acheives a huge success in staying in the middle of the road.

Reddish brown with a light tan head.  Sweet caramel and dark fruit.  Light spice.  Brown sugar.  Slightly fuller body with low carbonation.  Sweet full caramel.  Prune, dark fruit.  Light bit of astringency in the finish.  Lingering subtle spice.  Not a bad beer, under my radar!

Bottle from new beer i think.  Pours a dark mahogany brown body with a thin off white lacing.  Dark fruits, plum, raisins.  Hints of smoked meat and molasses.  Licorice and some chewy toffee and a light coffee bitterness.  Nice alcohol warming with dark malts rounding this one out.  Real good brew.

Dark brown with a very small head that dissipates.  Aroma is very malty with some raisin, toffee, light chocolate, and molasses.  Taste is full bodied and very malty- some light dark fruit, toffee, taffy, molasses.  Carbonation is very light for the style.  Finishes a bit sweet with toffee, and molasses.

I got a bottle of the 9.0ABV version, and it’s delicious.  Dark brown with a very thin white head that dissipates quickly.  Yes I can feel the complexity but I’m not educated enough to identify all the flavors listed in the description.  It is deep flavored, sweet, I can taste the fruitiness and the light coffee flavoring.  It has what is to me an unidentifiable European quality... I can taste that it came from the old country.  This is the first time I’ve seen this here in Buffalo, and I think this was the last bottle of the dark... I hope to see it again.  Very nice beer.
Dark brown pour, nearly black, wit ha thin white head. Malty aroma of sugary dark fruit. Flavor is deep and rich, very sweet malt wit ha hint of nuttiness. Subtle alcohol presence. Very, very good.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2009 Bottle. OMG!! This is my new favorite beer!! You take the best elements of all doppelbocks and add a touch of the great abt/quadruples and this is what you get. Wonderful dark color with a slightly sweet flavor that reminds me of Christmas, (Must be the time of the year). Ok, I pray this one stays in our area. I believe I might be drinking it for years to come. This one is WAY underrated. Highly recommended . (Rerated Because I had better beers since)

tap at Trappeze in Athens.
Pours amber with thin head.
Aroma is very malty and chocolate and fruity..
Taste, lots of malts with a thick mouthfeel that has plenty of caramel - molasses.
Beer is smooth with an almost sweet honeyish, dark fruity feel on the palate. Finish is dry and hoppy. There is also a very faint trace of smoke.

Aroma is a massive malty, spice bomb, with cinnamon and ginger foremost, some kirsch, also pheffernusse cookies, garnet, pours a fair sized toffee head.
  Roasty malt, brazil nuts, demerara sugar, birch, pitfruits galore, touch of allspice. Full bodied, extremely well balanced, complex, bitter as the be jeez, the closest beer I have had to Ayinger Celebrator, and that is saying something folks. Wonderous exclamation point goes here

Dark amber. Medium creamy head. 

Aroma: Caramel, fruits. 

Flavor: Caramel, toasted malt, bread. Chewy.

Finish. Sweet fruits.

This is a great beer, perhaps under-rated a bit.

Just one massive dopplebock! I’m going off memory here but I remember it well. Pours a very dark brown almost black with some good fluffy tan head. Flavor is certainly on the sweet side with lots of molasses and port flavors some fig and raisin. Aroma was big and full of toasted malt with some sweet and spicy notes. A little too much alcohol is present in the flavor, but the beer retains a silky mouthfeel and not a lot of harshness from the alcohol.

Funky, lots of fruit, like apple pie up front, mild acidity, almost like a sour brown. The body was very thin and the tartness was not what I was expecting for the style. Pours dark brown with a thin beige head. I just think this beer had something wrong with it, not awful, but not like a doppelbock.

Pours dark brown with burgandy highlights and fair, but unsustainable big bubble light tan head. Flavors of rum soaked fruit, toffee, anise, and some alcohol.  Medium full very chewy body has a soft mouthfeel.  Alcohol warming finish is not offensive at all.  Not that expensive and good for style, winning combo in my book.

500ml Bottle: Aroma of figs, port, light chocolate, toffee, light coffee, caramel, light molasses, nuts, dark malts, and brown sugar.  Poured light brown/copper in color with a small to medium-sized, dense, fizzy, beige head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Tastes of dark malts, chocolate, coffee, molasses, brown sugar, light caramel, toffee, slight tar, and toasting.  Medium to full body.  Smooth, slightly oily texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Sweet, malty, brown sugar finish.

Burnt Molasses and caramel flavors with a a little honey a maple syrup notes.  An excellent dopplebock.  Small quickly diminishing head with virtually no lacing.  Medium bodied.  Dark amber/red color.   Moderately sweet initial flavor with a lightly bitter finish.  A syrupy texture with soft carbonation.

Tap @ BBF ’08. Dark brown beer, beige head. Aroma of burnt malts, caramel, a bit of rye. Flavour is sweet, malty, deep roasted malts, some coffee indeed, surprisingly spicy finish. Fullbodied. Not an average bock.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2009 Ayinger Celebrator step aside. This is the new king of dobbelbocks. Pours a dark ruby- almost black- with a small off-white head. Nose is very sweet with lots of malt, caramel, raisins, milk chocolate, and dark fruits. Taste is chocolately and sweet with a lot of malted milk ball taste. The hops refuse to kick in until the very end and create a nice balanced finale. Excellent- perhaps a little too sweet.

Shared this one with my friend Gyurke in Wiesbaden.  Pours a nice deep golden brown color.  Aromas of rich dark malts, chocolate, fruit.  Flavor is rich with a lot of flavors light chocolate, dark fruit, smoke, coffee.

Slight gushing fills the neck then pours a dark ruby body looks black away from the light with a thin but lasting cover of light tan almost off white head.  Creamy chewy aromas, prunes, plums, chocolate and mollasses some brine and licorice.  Taste is very chocolatey more salty brine and licorince then a strong alcohol finish.  A heavy palated finish of prunes and chocolate lingers.

Beautiful ruby red/chestnut brown appearance, modest off-white head.  Nice malty aroma, with notes of dark fruits, raisins, caramel.  The flavor caramel, fruits like raisins, figs.  The finish is a little wierd: a decent balancing act between the sweet fruit and the subtle, slightly bittering hops.   I think some of this bittering may come from roasted malts as well.  Finally, the finish is a little sour.  Good dopplebock overall.

Bottle. Pours beautifully, you can see the carbonation bubbles jumbling all around inside the glass. A dark red almost a brown in color. Coffee, nut to the nose and a bit of something I can’t put my finger on.

I was expecting a little more although it was tasty.

50cl bottle from Kingdom Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark brownish red to black color with one finger tan head. Aroma is malted milk, chocolate, some dark ripe fruit, sweet caramel. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of chocolate, dark ripe fruit, strong malt notes, and slight coffee bitterness close to finish. Medium to full body with a smooth, warm, slightly sweet, slightly bitter alcohol finish.

Bottle. Poured brown with a creamy tan head that settles to a ring and left light lace. Aromas of raisin, prune, brown sugar, and a malt backing. The flavor is sticky with prune, caramel and a light roast. Full body, sweet, smooth, soft carbonation. Very enjoyable.
Botttle.  Poured a dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt, roasted malt, caramel and dark fruit.  Flavor was rich and sweet with a bit of warming alcohol.  Great beer.

(Bottle).  Sweet fruity/smokey aroma.  Deep reddish brown color, thin light tan head.   Flavor is very different and distinctive for the style.  Lots of fig and  caramel, along with roasted/smoked mussels as an undertone.  Sweet , but not overwhelmingly so.  Not sure I love this, but I can appreciate its complexity.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2008 Big malt aroma, lots of caramel, raisins, figs. Great rich flavor, thick and tasty but with an alcohol-strong, drying finish that balances it well. A great Doppelbock; one of the best.

Shared by turdferguson. Pours a dark brown with some ruby highlights. The head was one to two fingers thick creamy and light tan. The nose is sweet, lightly boozy, some astringency, strange noodle aroma, and as Sam said some vegetal notes. The flavor was very tricky, it starts off very unassuming and not necessarily unpleasant (not pleasant either). Then it gradually builds to become intolerable. Notes of alcohol, grain, sweetness, astringency. The mouthfeel was astringent and harsh. Finishes awful. Not sure if this was a bad bottle or what but me no likey.

Bottle sent by lithy. Thanks Justin. Pours a deep, layered, reddish brown with a small tan lace. Nose is sticky buns, caramel, yeast, dough, and slightly vegetal. Flavor seems a bit off, perhaps this is a bad bottle, more vegetal flavors and aggressive alcohol that leaves an unpleasant taste in the mouth. Meh.

Bottle.  Slightly cloudy brown pour with a thin coffee head.  Aroma of raisins, caramel and cherry.  Taste is somewhat thin but enjoyable with bread, caramel and sugar present with some underlaying molasses.  Smooth finish.

Bottle into Corsendonk tulip, purchased at West Lakeview Liquors.  I always jump at the chance to have a doppelbock I haven’t seen, in the hopes that there will be a challenger to Celebrator.  Alas, the search continues (although this got the closest of any).  Murky brown in the glass looks a little watery, the head is thin and barely lasting, but produces some nice "racing."  Smell doesn’t fill the sinuses like the best of them, but it’s pretty strong, and is kind of wonderful:  dark bread, toffee, caramel, and underneath is a wonderful winey fruitiness.  Fairly light bodied, definitely as thin as it looked, but the flavor buoys the feel to keep this from being watery: initial mouthful of bready, toffee malts that coat the whole mouth, pretty strightforward but delicious; then, they fade and you are about to ask, "Is that it?" when a second layer surges forward with darker, almost woody malt flavor that is reminiscent of the winey notes in the aroma with overripe fruits, fruitcake, and twigs.  It’s not dry, but I can’t seem to get any spittle on top of my tongue; maybe that’s the alcohol, but there isn’t any other indication of it.  Damn nice doppelbock.  Glad I bought it.

Draught. Pours dark brown with reddish highlights, medium off-white head with no real lacing. Aroma is sweet - molasses and a bit of a dark fruit quality, hint of alcohol. Taste is hugely sweet malt up front- molasses, caramelized brown sugar, rum-soaked dark fruit quality, with no detectable roasty notes. Just a hint of smoke in there to, that emerges a bit more in the finish. Finish is rich, a bit dry, with a faint earthy bitterness that balances the sweetness without ever really emerging from it. Body is rich and full, not quite syrupy, with subdued carbonation. Really a decadent dessert treat. Fantastic.

on draft, beachwood bbq

reddish brown pour, flavor is sweet with notes of cherries and raisins. THere were other ccomplexities I couldn’t make out. both my wife & I liked it

RB DE#1000: 50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden deep amber with a lacing tan head. Spiced and roasted malt aroma, mild fruity touch. Sweet and solid caramel malt in the first sip, followed by a more roasted malt and breadish note. Lingering dark fruity and breadish finish.

Pours a red brown with a medium beige foamy head.  Sweet raisin, toasty biscuit, jam on english muffin and wonderful german yeast aroma.  Flavor is very vinous, sherry, port, not as much roast as I was expecting, some banana esters, a little bit burnt, some molasses, chocolate syrup, quite rich.  Fluffy body, not syrupy like a lot of doppelbocks.  Odd bitter tobacco, fig finish.
Deep robust garnet pour, slight off white head.  rich aroma, figs, sweet molasses, raisins.  chewy mouthfeel with sour cherries, sweet molasses malt backbone with a slight burnt/roast note at the en

pours a deep garnet with little head. aroma of tart cherry, sweet malt, molasses, and trace of alcohol. Flavor is very solid- cherry still there, fig, molasses, and present alcohol. palate starts thin, but builds into a very nice mouthfeel. very tasty brew.
Rich caramel aroma.  Super flavor, like drinking a not-too-sweet fruitcake.  Aftertaste of light grassy hops and dried fruit astringency.

Beautiful brown in colour, light beige coloured head, good lacing.  The aroma is roasty, light smoke, lots of malt, mild sweetness, caramel, chocolate.  The flavour is mildly sweet, lots of dark malts, fruit sweetness, some cherries, black forest cake and some alcohol.  Creamy mouthfeel, medium/large body, moderate carbonation.  Finishes lingering, sweet, malty and warm.
Excellent mouthfeel, this might be the perfect winter beer, quite rich but very hardy.
500ml bottle from the Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York.
Opened on January 27, 2008.
No date.

(GERMAN) Nice dark brown color with a sm-tan head. Aroma is of dark chocolate, liqorice, and raisins. The taste is yummy, with dry fruits, molasses, and coffee notes. The finish is dry and the 9% is well hidden in this doppelbock. Well balanced, and worth a taste !!!

Bottle: Pours a dark brown color with light head. The nose is very sweet and fruity with a ton of maple and malt notes. The flavor is wet and juicy; grapes, fig, molasses, coffee. Bright alcohol and lots of nutty cherry notes in the flavor. Huge body and a creamy mouthfeel. Not for the faint of palates.
Bottle at Au Trappiste, Paris. Pours brown with a stable yellowish head. Mostly caramel aroma. Tastes of nutty caramel with good bitterness to offset the sweet malts. Full-bodied. Quite nice.
This beer has a good aroma and a quite average appearance. It is a full-bodied and smoky tasting beer with dark fruit flavoring. Very good.
Bottle; pours dark brown, but held up to light shows a coppery/ruby-ish core; sweet malty aromas with coffee, dried fruits, and yeasty baked goods on the nose and palate; great beer at a great price

J Betskis Raleigh, NC Bottle 5/16/08. Poured a lacy lower head underneath a tight creamy beige top. Deep brown with subtle copper hues around the edges. The head quickly diminishes into thin and creamy, barely covering the surface. Aroma  of dark fruit pie, figs, molasses, dates and spice. Excellent first sip, difficult to pinpoint one main characteristic. Sweet, sour, earthy, rich, fruity, yeasty. Try this one but let it warm up for the full effect.

500ml bottle from mcbackcus and Knightly Spirits; Nose is caramel, toffee, and raisins; clear rusty brown with a small beige head; flavor is sweet, candied raisins, caramel, and a bit of hop bitterness. Finish is sweet and caramelly with a hint of bitterness at the very end.

Theres not much I can say about this then the commercial description has not already stated.  This is a truly delicious example of this style.  Definitely has the fruitcake, with a viscous mouthfeel, and a lingering sweetness on the palate, and some roasty coffee notes in the finish.

Bottle 500 ml 
Appearance:  Chestnut brown with medium dense slightly tanned top.4-Nose : Solid sweet ripe fruit aroma , berry like with gentle nutty side. Caramel with gentle brown malt accents. Very clean and mature malted set up.  Flavor/Palate :Woah , medium full brew with exquisite falvour bouquet. Dark caramel with raisin , sweet quality malt , soft wrapping smoothness of alcohol shall. Big yet not overly heavy , somehow it finds balance that should not be. Just right dose of alcohol , sweetness from malt and bit of magic. Must have in doppel bock world!

Espresso-mocha aroma. Dark-brown/black color with thin layer of white head. Multiple layers of flavor: raisin, molasses, chocolate roasted maltiness.  Alcohol is well masked by the strong and balanced hop flavors on the side of the tongue. Could have used a bit more carbonation.
500ml bottle. Pours clear copper in color with full foamy brown head. Aroma sweet and caramel. Taste of sweet roasted malt and caramel with dry finish.

Bottle 50cl. Mahagony colour, small head, soft carbonation. No bitterness at all, slight hops in the background. Roasted malt, notes of coffee dominate. Balanced, hides the 7%vol alc very well. Ambrosia!

Draught at Schlosshotel Linderhof, 5 minutes walk from Ludwigs II castle Linderhof.
Clear amber coloured, small beige head, malty nose. Malty, toffee, dark fruits and chocolate aroma with notes of licorice, roasted coffee and smoke. Quite oily, bitter finish and long-lasting bitter aftertaste. 9% is well hidden.

Excellent example of the style.  All malt on the nose and the palate.  Faint flavors of dried fruit and chewy sugary-ness as well.  Delicious aromas and flavor.  The only spot where this one falls short is the appearance on the pour.  Seemed a bit thin and weak on the pour.  I was pleasantly surprised once I put it to my nose and lips, but if I had to have a critique of this one, it would be on the pour.  But - that being said - I would happily order this one whenever I see it available...  and doppelbocks are my favorite style of all beers.  Delicious.

an amazing example of the type.  malt malt malt on the nose. malt malt malt all throughout the palate with just a touch of very faint hop bitterness at the back of the palate.  those monks know how to extract some sugar!!!  excellent

16.9oz bottle. aroma is dark fruits, dark caramel, nutty, mild earthiness, and a nice maltiness. Dark red, bordering on brown, with a khaki colored, one fingered head. Initial taste is malty, with some caramelized sugars, dark fruits, and light floral followed by rich malt, showcasing melanoidins and biscuty flavors, along with a small amount of roast, and dark caramel. Nice body, nice finish. Good dopplebock!

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2009 Poured from a large-sized bottle into a pint glass.  A great aroma, featuring a mixture of raisins and figs, darker fruits, and some caramel too; a bit of roastyness.  Pretty good taste, slightly sweet start, switching over to bitterness, definitely a good presence of raisin and fruit.  The color is a dark brown-red, with a smaller sized, off-white, foamy head that had very modest cling and retention.  Quite wet mouthfeel with a small amount of carbonation; very smooth with a slight alcohol finish.  This beer is a good one, with a consistent match between aroma and taste.
The bottle looks really good, the beer in the glass also. Fine foam for a doppelbock. Not too malty, but a little bit fruity. Really good!
pours dark brown cola like,thin white head fades fast.raisin,prunes,cherrry,carmel.tones on the nose.Sweet up front,dry finish.Hints of dark fruit.OK

Sampled at the Cellars weekly beer tasting in St. Paul.  Dark brown (almost like Coke) in color with a thin tan head.  Aroma of caramel malt and some pitted fruits.  Flavor is caramel and molasses with some sweet coffee notes.

500ml bottle. Pours into my krug a clear mahogany with a nice, creamy tan head. Toffee and caramel nose, dark fruitiness. Big and sweet, the flavors come on strong - toffee, roasty malt, licorice, molasses.. all dipped in mild rum. Delish! As it warms up, more fruit shows, dark berries and fig. Sweet not not sticky, full but not overbearing, the rich flavors are addictive. Excellent.
Dark copper color with no head.  Strong aroma of malt syrup.  Quite spicy at first sip.  Thin malt and a bit of wheat.  The spices seem to be cloves and anise.  Very fine!

Deep cola coloured body with a thinnish light brown head - nice and ruby coloured tint near the bottom - very transparent! Aroma of nice fresh malt, brown sugar, maple, smoke and even a bit of prunes. Full-bodied; Strong malty taste with a lot of sugars, plentiful spices and a good dose of potent anise and clove flavours. Aftertaste shows nicely - chewy malty tastes throughout with enough sugar to be a dessert. Overall, a good doppelbock - strong up front but fading to a nice end! I sampled this 500 mL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Clarendon (Arlington), Virginia on 24-February-2008.

Pours nice dark brown with big tan head. Aroma is very eclectic mix of dried fruits, molasses, and roasted malts. Flavor is also very good, the dried fruits headline, with the malts and alcohol make for a nice finish. A very solid doppelbock, could use a slightly better balance of the dried fruits and malts, but still one of the better ones Ive had.
Chocolate malts and fruit really shine through in this dopple compared to most. Very smooth body, though somewhat boozy. Toffee notes.  Certainly a step above the crowd, but not overly so.

A small off-white head quickly departs from the clear, darkish mahogany beverage. Whew! Rich nose, heady and warming just from the smell. Mostly focused on fruitiness. Theres obviously a fair toasted munich base, but your attention resides on fruity alcohol. I would not call it vinous, but the vapors are strong enough that it reminded of Cognac. Nutty and lightly roasty upon the finish. Neglectable hops. I was a bit surprised at the lightness of the palate, light-medium bodied at most, but the texture is silky. It flows and rolls on the tongue. Comfortable indeed, but the effervescent bite removes a bit from the enjoyable fruitiness. Its dark grapes, cherries and blackberries, with enough dark, almost roasted malts to avoid any juicy impression. Sweet, but certainly under control in that department, never cloying and more warming than anything, the body is light enough to avoid any stickiness. A serious and rich example that does not quite strike the sensible never with me. I prefer a very focused toastiness and less alcohol. Complex lager though.

First off, its a tad thin on the palate and the aroma is weak but everything else works extremely well. highly malty, strong taste of cola, caramel and a little licorice. 
A great beer.

Very nice.  Celebrator has long been my favorite doppelbock and one without peer.  This comes close.  Pours a deep chestnut with an impressive tan head.  The aroma is rich caramel malts, some pine hops, a hint of smoke, some chocolate, and bread dough.  The aroma is rich without being overpowering.  It entices rather than kidnaps.  The flavor is a nice balance of the sweet and the bitter with the hint of smoke. Well done.

Pours deep mahogany into a stem glass. Fluffy off-white head with little retention pancakes as it recedes without lacing. Plum and molasses aromas.  Upfront figs with a lasting hop and cherry  fruitcake finish.
500 ml bottle.  Dark pour with little head.  Aromas are all dark fruit and caramel.  Raisin, anise, malty.  Flavor is very similar with just a touch of alcohol in the finish.  Very very good.

Poured from bottle into Sam Adams tasting glass. Essentially zero head. The aroma is very malty with hints of caramel, and perhaps bananas or bubble gum. The flavor is huge, rich, and sweet. The tasty is very malty and chocolatey. The flavor is big on sweetness with very little bittering. The mouthfeel is great. The finish is fast, with very little aftertaste. For some reason the beer strikes me as too sweet for a session beer, but then again I could easily imagine myself drinking many of these in a short amount of time.

Draught at Chef Pauls in Lisle.  Pours dark brown, mahogany with a very thing head that laces the glass delicately.  A deep aroma reminiscent of tawny port and chocolate.  Very good beer, rich sweetness, molasses, roast nutty flavor and not overly sweet or cloying.  Rich creamy palate.  Im impressed!

Pours deep mahogany with a crimson hue and a small tan head.  The aroma has chewy biscuit, toffee, creamy chocolate, smooth toasty malt and ice cream malt.  Medium smooth creamy body with semi-soft carbonation.  The flavor starts with bready caramel, sweet toffee and a dry-ish brown sugar.  The finish has some oxidation showing and lots of spice.  A good doppelbock.

Draught at Chef Pauls in Lisle, IL. Faint and German aroma. Clear dark red body with a good-sized tan head. Excellent lace. Great color. Smooth, sweet, German Dunkelish character. Excellent and very enjoyable.

Bottle. Brown-red pour with a tan head. Aroma of sweet malt and some earthy elements as well. Flavors of sweet caramel, malt, cream soda and a bit of booze. Medium bottle, sweet with a sweet malty finish. Not bad, but not all that great either...the cream soda element was off-putting.

Bottle received via trade with porterhouse.  Pours deep brown with an average, frothy, light brown head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (caramel, toffee, nutty), light hops (grass), average yeast (broth, dough) with notes of figs, cherries, port, and molasses.  Full bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a slight bitter, metallic finish.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

Recieved September 2006, Sampled December 2007
Pours with an initially, almost three-finger thick, lightly darkened, tan colored head that has a bit of staying power to it.  The beer sits in my glass a concentrated, blackened, amber tinged color but does show a brilliantly clear, concentrated ruby red color when held up to the light.  Rich, sweet malt aromatics define the nose of this beer.  Almost no hop aromatics, in fact I cant really smell any.  Aromas of figs, richly caramelized malt, broiled raisins, musty concentrated dark fruits.  The aroma has almost smells like it has cork taint, that musty, slightly off cork smell of TCA seems to be here, but I have no idea how that could be.  This may just be a bit of oxidation setting in, but it is a bit unusual for it to take this form.  Irregardless, the aroma is rich and malty enough that it is able to overcome this and still remain quite enjoyable.

Sweet and richly concentrated malt notes as well as brandy like warming alcohol flavors are noticeable in the first sip.  This is really rich and chewy, without being overly sweet though; the malt sugars here are complex enough that the sweetness is not cloying.  This is definitely a meal in a glass; the heft of this brew is impressive, it has both a viscous weight to it and a palate coating quality that sticks to the mouth even after a sip has been swallowed.  A touch more hoppy than the aroma suggested, there are hints of herbal (at times even menthol like), hop derived flavors here as well as a soft, fleeting, though lingering, hop bitterness in the finish.  Clearly though this beer is about the malt.  Concentrated & powerful, flavors of dark chocolate, toasted grain, lightly bitter burnt malt and dark whole grain toast provides a slight counterpoint to the sweeter malt flavors.  As the beer warms & loses the medium carbonation it becomes much more creamy feeling, though it also begins to pick up a touch of that TCA like mustiness from the aroma.

What a tasty, totally rich & satiating, thoroughly enjoyable beer, while the lack of that TCA like component would have made this perfection in a glass, it still does not hurt it enough to make this less that incredible.  This is exactly what I have been looking for in a Doppelbock lately.  If you are a malt lover, you have got to try this beer, it will totally satisfy any malt cravings you may have.

Poured a dark yet thin chestnut aphotic brown build with a quickly deduced soapy white cranium.  Earthy, peety, grape and dark fruit nose. Sapidity of fulgent sweet port wine and roasted cherries.  Finishes with a smoky lush earthiness.  bold and complex.  Quite unique.
Deep red. Malty aroma, touch of caramel. Rather rich. Flavor has all of the above and some fruit as an added bonus. Not as smooth and complex as Ayinger Celebrator, by which I measure all top beers.

Had this @ The Winking Lizard on Bethel while watching the Arizona Oregon game with my boys Spencer & Scott.  Nose of caramel, apples and pears, berries.  Pours a clear garnet.   The tall frothy off-white/beige head leaves light lace.  The sweet and bready front is followed by alcohol warmth and sweetness in the middle with no acidity.  The floral finish is sweet and long.  The medium creamy/syrupy body is soft to lively with a slightly alcoholic feel to the finish.  We followed this one with a car bomb before we headed out.  Ouch!!

Bottle. Mahogony beer with a small light tan head. Rich caramel, fig, raisin aroma. Rich caramel, raisin, fig, brown sugar flavor with a bit of earthiness. Medium body. Alcohol well hidden. Doesnt finish as rich. Earthiness, caramel lingers with a bit of tinniness.
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2007 Everything a doppelbock needs to be. Better, I thought, even than Ayingers Celebrator. A nice hop balance with the sweet malt. Keep this one.

Bottle at Monks in Philly. This is one of the best beers I ever had, period! The complexity of the smells was awesome. Very fruity and malty. The taste was just as complex but perfectly consistent. This was the last beer of the day and Im glad I stumbled upon it. Now I need to hunt it down for a case. This is truly a wonderful beer.

Darker brown pour with a ruby hue.  Aroma is rich and sweet - figs, raisins, caramel, molasses, and some sugary malt detectable.  Flavor is a tad sharp and sugary - molasses, brown sugar, raisin, and a bit of alcohol.  Nice mouthfeel with a slight burn at the finish.  Pretty good D-bock.

@Old Bay-pours with no head and mahogany color.  Aroma is dark malt-molasses, dark fruit-plum, spice.  Taste is syrupy/sweet, dark malt-molasses, dark fruit-plum, spice-coriander-like, alcohol.  Sipping to start.  Medium/full body.  OK carbonation.
Nice Dopplebock. Lots of caramel and fig, a little too sweet, but very nice.
50cl bottle.  Pours clear and amber with a thin light brown head.  Aroma is sweet and roasty and palate is almost syrupy.  Taste is very sweet with intense fruit notes.  Enjoy this one slowly.

Bottle (thanks to toadman). Pours a clear amber-red with quickly vanishing tan head.  Aroma is lightly toasted bread and a little dark fruit.  Taste is smooth sweet caramel and figs. Chewy doughy mouthfeel.  I barely taste the 9%.  Very nice.

Tap.  Pours a darker red tinged brown with a fairly large tannish head.  Nose is sweet and fruity.  Flavor is dense and rich, slightly roasted but dried fruit (prunes...oops dried plums) with dark brown sugar sweetness.  This was delicious although certainly not a session brew but rather to be savored.

Smell: Sweet-smelling, rich aroma of syrupy malts along with notes of cinnamon, sugar-soaked dark fruits, and molasses. 

Taste: Sweet, sticky maltiness with flavors of toasted toffee, brown sugar, and just a drizzle of molasses. Copious amounts of lush darks fruits like figs and raisins. Hints of cinnamon and tobacco. Theres a faint mint character that emerges near the fruity finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Ample carbonation. Nicely warming.

Drinkability: I may not remember much, but I will never forget the time I shared an Ettaler Curator with my pal, Ando.

Dark thick black pour with a thin white head that quickly vanishes.   The nose sweetens up as the beer warms.  Hints of chocolate cake, dark fruit, roasted malt and other sweet dessert goodness.  Tastes of dark fruit (figs and plums) dominate the other subtler flavors of coffee and chocolate.  The beer is lightly carbonated and sits beautifully on the tongue.  Highly recommended doppelbock.
A good sweet and dried fruity doppelbock.  Tasted at the Iowa City Brewfest.  Dried fruits, caramel, port, etc.  Malty.

Pours maple brown with no head.  Aroma is strong maple syrup, brown sugar, dark fruit, molasses, and a good amount of grain.  Flavor is quite similar with a bit of roastiness thrown in for good measure.  I dont really taste much hoppiness.  Extremely sweet and a good beer for fall.

(Alko, 7 % 0.5 l bottle). Best before just gone, this pours with a small disappearing head and darkish red brown looks. Quite sweet nose with a lot of malts. Darker reddish brown, moderate head with solid lacing and retention. Aroma is very inviting and sweet. Notes of caramel, bread, toast, hint of fruit, roast and alcohol. Medium to heavy body, sweet as usual. Enjoyable example.

16.9 black in color with ruby highlights. light tan head is short lived. plums and figs appear on the nose along with milk chocolate and black coffee. sweet chocolatey start with a solid palate. rich malts are fairly robust. sticky middle unleashes coffee, and chocolate flavors and hints of licorice. the best feature of this beer is the the well hoped finish. it is long and refreshingly bitter.

Dark pour with little head. Aroma kinda subdued. Read the descript. Its there just not in yer face.
 Tasted of Raisins ,dried plums,black licorice,chocolate,hints of dark bread and dark cherries. And of course pretty damn malty. Abv hidden. Slightly sticky mouthfeel. $3.69 a pint cant go wrong.

Pours a nice dense brown color with a slight purple hue.  Malty, chalky, full bodied flavor.  Slight alcohol bite.  Aromas of licorice and plum.  Faint wheat flavors.  Faint sugary finish.  Bottle from Brawleys Beverage.

Bottle (500ml) shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, mds & tupalev -- courtesy of mds. Pours a clear deep ruby-copper with a spare diminishing off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, dark fruit and some light smoke. Flavours predominantly caramel malt along with some light spices and dark fruit. Medium bodied. Pretty good, nothing special but its fine.
nice colour of copper. the head is small and not very solid. smell is alcoholic and malty (roasted). alcoholic and malty taste, the mid brings hops. ends up quite boring without new accents.

Bottle shared with Blankboy, GregClow, Mds, and Hogtown Harry, courtesy of mds.  Dark brown, no head.  Mild malt aroma.  Great taste - rich malt, light to medium body, some assertive bitterness as well.  Spicy, earthy, very nice dopplebock.

Bottle shared with blankboy, HogTownHarry, mds and tupalev - courtesy of mds. Ruby-brown colour with a thin off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt, tobacco leaves and dark fruit. Medium mouthfeel. Flavour is quite complex, with notes of sweet malt, coffee, toffee and various spices. Very good.

The aroma has oddly lactose-like notes that remind me of malted strawberry milkshakes. Some solid vanilla, plum, raisin and cherry notes back up that ice cream parlor feel. Curious, but pleasant aroma. The body is a warm amber tinted brown and mahogany with a diminishing tan head. Big malt fore with a kiss of alcohol that fades quickly beneath an onslaught of fruit notes that run the gambit of the worlds orchards. Some light spice and even a sort of leathery, raisiny-like tobacco note appears int he far aftertaste. The alcohol content is almost unnoticeable after that first little kick.

Pours a clear blood red, absolutely gorgeous hue, resembling a filtered cabernet with blackberry syrup added. Really just an astonishing hue, in any medium. A creamy beige head with slight creamsicle hues fades slowly, never fully, leaving behind lacing that looks like oily paintings of dirty-snow-capped mountain ranges off in the distance. The aroma is loaded with character, malty as all get out and fun to attmept to break down. Notes of caramel, plums, licorice sticks, raisins, espresso beans, vanilla, toffee, hints of chocolate, peaches and banana. What a blend! The flavor is an understated competition crusher, bearing down on the palate without overdoing anything or becoming scattered, muffled or mismanaged. Dark fruits and roasty malts, plenty of cereal grains, light tartness and caramel galore all meld into a delightful flavor. Sweetness is medium-high and never nears cloying due to its endearing counterparts and loads of accomplices in this treasure of a taste. Bitterness is low to mild, no acidity but for the hints implicated by a light, tart fruitiness near the end of each sip. The level of grain present is somewhat surprising but doesnt jar the flavor into something less than easily enjoyable and easygoing. The finish is raisiny, sweet and completed by lingering caramel and chocolate notes, slight nuttiness too, drying out signifigantly. The mouthfeel is zippy with good carbonation(even though it doesnt feel very natural), medium-full body, very smooth and a touch clumped/sticky. Smooth as hell nonetheless. Very impressive; one of very few Dopplebocks I enjoy more than the cult standard, Ayinger Celebrator. Fantastic and underrated!

Big explosion of flavor upon the first sip.  Alot of dark fruits, moslty berries, and syrupy malts.  A little sweet cinnamon shows up in there as well.  There is enough fruit to balance out the sugars and the alcohol is masked really well.  Just overall a well balanced brew.  Very solid representation of this style.

Bitter dry finish.  Sweet malts with flavors of toffee and vanilla anise spiciness.  Raisins and port.  Tart sweetness with a noticveable yet moderate alcohol burn.  Well done.

bottled. Musty malt & yeast nose, deep brown lager w/ a very minimal yet soapy head.  Sweet alcoholic dopplebock. Very nice, MUST BUY AGAIN.

Very stong hoppy dopplebock. A bit on the sweet side, but I suppose thats because of alcohol.
Dark brown color with small light brown head and little lacing. Aroma and flavor were very roasty and malty. It was a little sweet and fruity

This is a pretty good doppelbock.  A bit sweet and faintly shows too much of the alcohol in the finish, but overall this is drinkable and resemblant of a doppelbock of good style.

Deep ruby garnet, fairly clear, thin tan head. Sour oxidized apple nose. Thin, watery, a little sweet, oxidized apple cling for the finish. Simplistic. Neither refreshing not complex and satisfying.

Bottle. Pours a deep mahogony with a fairly think, light tan head that doesnt last very long. When it hits the toungue, wow. Raisens, fruit, molassas, brown sugar with alcohol in back.Smooth, creamy - almost chewy. This was good, I may try to grab another.

Half liter bottle. No freshness date seen. Poured out a dark amber color, with ruby highlights. Aromas are of fig preserves, raisins, prunes, malts, lots of stuff going on in the aromas. Flavors are of figs, prunes, sweet malts, licorice, slight hop bitterness.
Thick mouthfeel, rich & chewy. Decent body. Finished sweet, but not cloying.
Really good beer overall.

16.9oz bottle into a Dimpled Mug glass.  Wow!  What a surprise with this one!  Pours a darkish brown color with a hint of a dark red.  A big plummy nose intermixed with raisons and heavy sweet malts wavers from the glass.  The flavor is very deep in its areas touching in sweet malt, dark fruits, a tiny bit of chocolate, molasses, and a hint of alcohol in the body.  A bit complex, but mostly just flavorful all around.  Pretty smooth on the palate.  Overall, an incredibly enjoyable brew.  Definitely can feel the 9%!  I would drink this over and over again!!
Practically black.  Smells sweet, but tastes smoky, alcohol clearly present, which takes over all the other flavors in the beer.
pours a very dark brown, almost black, with a thin greenish tan head.  aroma is of dark fruits and dark malt.  flavor has notes of dark fruit, mint, herbal, raisins, chocolate.  pretty good.

Tap.  Pour dark amber, thin head, malty nose.  Very nice offering.  Was recommended by another patron, glad I experimented.
