Deep brown, white creamy head.  Nose held rich malty notes of plum, caramel, and rummy fruitcake, with lesser notes of chocolate and banana.  Malty caramelized toffee and dark fruity flavors are nicely balanced with a light hop bitterness and hints of booze.  Full bodied, soft carbonation and smooth, lightly bittersweet finish. On tap at My Place in Newtown, CT. Light malty nose. Dark amber color with a medium brown head. Sweet malty start finishing creamy.

On tap at Redbones BBQ.  Pours a lightly hazy brownish amber with a creamy off white lacing head.  Aroma of very sweet toasted malts, iced tea, some lemon and a malty graininess.  Flavor of sweet malts, some various fruits, banana, grains, molasses and iced tea. Nice Doppelbock.

Bottle from Super Saver. Poured into a Kloster Weltenburger glass. Pours deep brown in color with a little off white head. Sweet grainy aroma with a nice coffee and toffee notes. Bottle. 1 Pint .9 FL. OZ.  Very dark reddish-brown with creamy off-white head.  Malty, prune aroma.  Nice medium-full body with creamy texture. Sweet flavor with long, smooth finish.  Enjoyable beer.

Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours dark brown with a decent size light tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, and slight roast. The flavor is sweet, fruit, caramel, and has a nice heavy alcohol punch. Great body, excellent brew.

.5L bottle  ruby red backbone in a dark brown beer.  frothy heavy tan head.  aroma of malt syrup, licorice, smoked malts, port, toffee, and raisins.  smooth calm malt flavors.  hop bitterness finish.  very light texture, medium bodied.  Alcohol is hidden very well.  Overall:  a very balanced malt concoction.

Poured from bottle...Smelled of sweet molases...Poured a reddish brown with a tan head that didnt last too long...Taste was sweet, thick, syrupy, fruits, apples, cherries, with a nice slightly bitter finish...I really enjoyed this. Alcohol was very well hidden.

[bottle] Reddish brown in color with a very short white head. Aroma is fruity and alcoholic. Bready, chewy malt flavors, with some serious dark fruit and spiciness. Caramel sweetness and alcohol warmth round things out. Very good, overall.

Pours a dark copper color with an off-white head.  Aroma is sweet of dark fruits, chocolate, caramel, and a little alcohol.  Flavor is of dark fruits at first then the slight roastiness with chocolate, caramel, and toffee.  Finishes with a slight alcohol warming.  Not too bad, probably one of my favorite doppelbocks.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2007 Pours a dark mahogany with red edges and a beige head. Lovely sweet aroma of chocolate which also gives you a hint of the chocolates bitterness. Flavour of bitter chocolat with a great vinious feel. The palate is great - it is foamy and carbonated and kind of fills up your mouth with small nuances from the sweetness, over the vinious feel and the bitterness. Great beer. (Bottle)

Bottle. Pours a beautiful red mahogany with a medium foamy off white head. Aroma is sweet with a musky roasted feel and some dark chocolate. Extremely full mouthfeel, foamy, oily. Flavour has lots of roasted tones, with raisins, plums, some coffee and a general sweetness. Ends on a pleasant vinious note.

Bottle. Clear copper color with average fair lacing off-white head. Aroma is heavy malty, dark bread, roasted, caramel, sweet, fruit, berry. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is lively.
Plums and some malt in the aroma.  Almost black with a quickly receeding head.  Full and creamy palate.  The taste is chewy, malty, with hints of tobacco and very light hops.

16.9oz, no date.  Mine says 9% ABV.  Pours a clear dark ruby brown with a one finger fading beige head.  Aroma of raisins, toasted malts, toffee, brown sugar, and way in the background some slight anise and spearmint.  Flavor is slightly oxidized with some alcohol in addition to the aforementioned flavors.  This wasnt quite as sweet as the aroma led on and theres a pretty good amount of toast and molasses in the flavor.  Bitterness is low--3 on a 1-10 scale.  Considering the strength of this, the alcohol is fairly well masked.  Low-moderate carbonation with a medium body.  I thought this one was pretty good.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: I still think this is 7% not 9%. At any rate, sometimes on a cold evening you just need a nice chewy German doppelbock and this is one of my favorite examples of the style. The body is rich mahogany, with a warming malty presence. But theres just so much subtlety at work here too - herbal tang, breads, caramel, even a slightly pepper spice. This is really the kind of thing youll hate unless youre in absolutely the right mood. But on its own merits its soooo strong.
Dark fruits and caramel malts make up the aroma.Pours a deep mahogany with a large off white head.Lots of sweet malt and some fruit in the flavor.Thin to medium mouthfeel with a sweet finish.
apparently I liked it a lot.  another night in paris.  dont remember it but rated it on sight and I was sober.

Pours clear and beautiful red-black with about two fingers of loose off-white head. Aroma is super-sweet...all molasses and raisins. Thick in the mouth with a little toffee and coffee (toffee/coffee?!?...Hey, I calls em like I sees em...). Something seems a bit off with the flavor, kind of a fishy thing going in the middle here...may need to try a different bottle...till then Im forced to hum it..."Flavor" and "overall" are tanking due to this off flavor...Ill try another and re-rate...

Bottled.  Poured a darker tea brown with a majestic 1.5" initial cap of creamy beige head... settled down to a loose beige dusting after a minute or so.  The aroma was quite sweet and complex with notes of rich molasses, burnt figs, caramel, dry-roasted chocolate, and sweeter herbs were in there.. among others.  The flavor was rich and chock fulla toasty dark malts... semi-sweet chocolate, coffee, molassess, toffee, plums, figs, and complimentary alcohol laced throughout.  Heavy almost to the point of being syrupy on the palate.  The warm finish left a sticky blackstrap molasses feel in the lips with hints of dark fruit.  Very good stuff!

Dr. Pepper brown, dark yet clear with a lasting white head. Vegetal notes take a long time to fade above the dry, roasty malts below. A toffee sweetness also gets covered. It opens up late with additional ABV notes. Light stickiness to a smooth, middle-weight body. Theres no denying the alcohol which appears up-front in the flavor from the get-go. Sweet, caramely dark malts precede a quick finish of bitters. Oh yes. Finally. Let this warm.

Deep dark brown color with a medium tan head and patchy lacing. The aroma is bready malt and fruit. Medium-bodied and creamy with roasted malt, fruit (raisins) and caramel flavors. The finish is tart and fruity with touches of malt. A decent enough beer, although it doesnt really fit into the Doppelbock flavor profile that I prefer.

A rich aroma of raisins or dates and a maltiness that sort of sets it off from better than average. A very dark brown pour with almost no head and a weak lacing. A flavor of sweet dried fruit. Not much more than that but a full well rounded fruitiness. A palate that is just a shade better than average. It is rich without being thick. The carbonation is just a tad over but overall a solid palate. Overall a beer I would call well above average for the style. I had a Celebrator last night this beer is very close but just a tad rough around the edges.

500 ml bottle.  Dark brown ruby tinted brew with a thin tan/light brown head.  Aroma is very malty, sweet rye toast, a bit of wheat, light plummymalts as well.  Demerera sugar and some toffee.  A light herbal/grassy hop character as well.  Warming brings up some sweet vineous and cherry fruit notes.  Sweet and toasty finish with a lingering chewy plummy character.  Creamy texture.  Warming draws out a bit of vanilla/chocolate, raisin and mint on the back of the palate.  Great balance and a lovely beer.

I was promised flying cars by the year 2007, or the next best thing, a doppelbock very nearly like the Celebrator.  Unfortunately this doesnt fit its billing.  Its more like a scotch ale.  Syrupy, tart, hints of smoke.  Not nearly a mouthfeel worthy of the worlds finest doppelbocks.  Wheres the cracklng, crisp flavor-burst at the finish?
Noteworthy points for appearance.  Not the deepest dark doppel, mind you, but a big fat head, exactly a thumbs width.  Doesnt live up to the appearance standards of Pamela Andersons GREAT ASS! in her prime, but by beer standards, its nevertheless wood-inducing.

Sample poured from a bottle at the Winking Lizard Tavern (Crosswoods) in Columbus, Ohio on 1/23/2007...

Another really good doppelbock that has been added to the list of beers to pick up again and sample in a private setting...
Bottle: Dark brown with a white head. Aroma, roasted malts, earthy hops, some chocolate, and some yeast. Flavor, chocolate, coffee, some bready notes, and some fruits. Pretty good.

Sweet cereal aroma -- like oatmeal, or the baby mush I used to feed my kids.  Dark, but very clear, off-white head, good label and German pint bottle.  Metallic, dark syrup, very cereal flavor.  The flavor is a somewhat grotesque chariacature of the aroma.  Glad this one is going on the expense account.  Finishes out bitter and prune-fruity, over a medium-heavy body.  Viscous and leggy on the sides of the glass.

Pours a deep clear ruby brown with half an inch of off white foam. Okay head retention and lacing. Rather mild aroma - you have to look for it - but when you find it some ripe dark stone fruit and chocolate malt great you.

Sweetish flavor of chocolate, toffee, and cinnamon. Hops in the finish for balance only. Medium to full body, gentle smooth carbonation. Dry bitter chocolate, very ripe plum, and cinnamon in the aftertaste.

Savannah, Ga. - Habersham Beverage Warehouse - 500 ml bottle. Dark brown cola-like, slightly transparent  pour with a faint wispy off-white head.  Fresh aroma of raisins, bubble gum  and a hint of brandy. Flavor has some raisiny notes, just a hint of chocolate and some baked brown bread for good measure. Some molasses is swirling around in the  back end.  Thin, but chewy mouthfeel. One of those beers that is not great is any one area - but melds together well - the sum of the parts...yada yada...thus the 16 overall.

Pours a very deep brown, almost black with a two finger head that settles quickly to a thin cap. Even with the head fading so quickly the cap stays around for a long time, and theres more lacing than I expected.

Smell; mild hints of chocolate with a sweetness that reminds me of honey. Darks fruits are definitely present, but I cant see to pick anything out specifically.

Taste; chocolate cake and prunes are the first things that come to mind on the first couple of sips. And Im surprised to say that the combination works for me. The honey-like sweetness is there, as well as a slightly nutty bitterness in the finish. This is different than any other dopplebock that Ive ever had, and I like it alot.

Mouthfeel/Drinkability; mouthfeel is thick and full bodied with a fairly low carbonation, and the drinkability is good, especially since I cant detect any alcohol, other than a slight warming in my stomach.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: a solid doppelbock.  dark brown with small white head, the aroma is malty with hint of roasted barley.  sweet and caramelly flavor, full bodied.

In the 0.5L bottle from HyVee CB. Pours sepia black with a dense garnet in the light. Head is thick and sustained of a violet-beige color. Wonderful aroma of plums and toffee malt. Huge thick body and palate. Intense raisins and roasted malt experience. This is one fine german dopplebock. The high alcohol is very well masked. An easy drinker for a big beer.
Nice dark smoth doppelbock. Very dark color with not much head. Has kind of a dry drinkability to it.

Draft at firewaters....dark brown with reddish hues....malty aromas...moleasses on steroids....a candy toffee like taste...easy to drink....some bananas also detected...reminds me a little of schneider aventinus
Bottle. Reddish hued amber color. Some lacing. Toasted biscuity aroma. Very malty caramel flavor, toffee with a hint of roastiness; very smooth, perfect carbonation. Excellent doppelbock.

Massive off-white foamy head atop an uncarbonated cola looking pour.  Nice lacing.  Yeasty, estery banana bread aroma with slight hint of cloves.  Smooth lightly carbonated palate.  Sweet finish with hints of chocolate and a faint metallic aftertaste.  High abv well hidden throughout.  Seems to share many characteristics that I notice in wheat beers.  A fine and well crafted brew.

500 ml bottle from Surdyks in Minneapolis, MN (October 2006) consumed at cellar temperature in an Unibroue glass.  Large-bubbled light tan head decays quite slowly, scintillating and sparkling and leaving erratic lacing, atop a deep walnut-red nearly opaque body.....nose is lovely but a bit underpowered, milk chocolate and burnt caramel, a touch of fig and cherry, light earthy spiciness, just needs more oomph.....rich, decadent mouthfeel is perhaps a bit too dry at the finish but before that its very solid, juicy dark malts and dried fruits, caramel and apricots and figs and light roasty coffee notes all submerged in a delicate caramel crust....low carbonation, very smooth.  A pretty typical German doppelbock, nothing out of the ordinary, but the bar is so high that just being ordinary is....excellent.

Bottle... This beer rocks!... Clear, dark mahogany lager with a small, creamy, light brown head. Excellent retention.  Vinous nose with esters and phenols of maple, nuts, port, dark fruits, chocolate and a puff of hickory smoke. Sweet dark fruit flavor, chewy malts, port. Some alcohol and medium bitter. Full-bodied with a heavy/oily mouthfeel and modest carbonation. Sweet, fruity finish. World class find in a little wine/beer/cheese/printing/shipping store called WorkSmart and The Virginia Touch in Berryville, Va. <<-- Now, thats a plug!
Bottle:  Im not normally so lazy but the commercial description is fairly accurate.  This is a very nice winter brew and the price makes it even more attractive!
not a bad doppelbach.  nice maltiness, toffee taste and some fruitiness.  not my favorite, but $2.99  for a 9% beer that is very drinkable, you cant beat that.
Very dark red color with a cream ring. Aroma is a very rich malt and some smoke. Very rich flavor, no hint of the 9% alcohol lurking.  Impressive.
Pours a dark brown with a small tan head.  The aroma has notes of dark fruit, chocolate, coffee, and caramel.  The flavor is complex with roasted coffee, dark chocolate and fruit, and tofee.

Draft - Poured a deep brown color with very little head.  Raisen, fruit, sweet aroma.  I prefer doppelbocks like Andechs with a much more creamy roasted malt character rather than the sweetness this beer has.

Clear, brilliant mahogany - thin head. Raisin, prune and rye bread aroma. Very sweet at first, with rasinesque flavors at first, then some smoky, rye, toasty flavors. Some whiskey notes, too. Tasty stuff.

(tap at Gingerman) Burgundy body topped by a tan ring.  A touch of smoke and some burnt rubber on the nose.  Very malty body a creamy texture.  Taste is surprisingly fruity & vinous (dark stuff) with a burnt caramel finish.  Alcohol remains well hidden in that thick body.  While not overly complex, this beer feels rich and filling and well focussed on its flavour spectrum.  That Curator has a nice flavour collection that deserves to be exhibited.

courtesy of oh6gdx - pours a clear dark brown colour with a reddish hue; very little foam remaining; the nose is a little bit sourish, roasted with strong notes of caramel, dates and a touch of alcohol; sweet and medium-bodied, tart and sour; dry and astringent bitter finish - it really does not work for me

Any first impressions?
-A ring of foam circles the clear, regal burgundy.
-Black grapes, raisins, and figs are all slowly caramelizing in the nose.
-Roasted malts are accompanied by a plethora of dark fruit, namely blackberries and raisins.
-The healthy mouthfeel is helped by the smooth carbonation.

What if you dig deeper?
-Alcohol is very well hidden for this gravity, making this a rather drinkable doppelbock.
-The flavor spectrum isnt too large, but quite complex within its range.
-A little more caramelization would have hooked me even more, but as is it stands as a very good, fruity example of this malt lovers style.

On tap at Gingerman, Manhattan.
Dark clear brown body, tan head. Nose was fruit, like raisins, coffee, roasted malts.Some light hops. Taste was all the nose with some sweet sour maltiness. Not a bad dopplebock here. Reccomend.

500ml bottle.  Nicely full and malty aroma, plenty of dark breadiness, roastiness and toffeeish sweetness, combined with notes of milky chocolate, dates, molasses and some faint spicy, alcoholic tinges and background earthiness.  Clear deep brown color with red highlights and a fine, receding off-white head.  Flavor seems to really come alive at around 60 deg. F, showing a range of dark malt character throughout including raisin, more roastiness and chocolate and with a somewhat burnt sugar aspect that manages to largely dry out before all is said and done.  Finishes with hints of licorice, subtle hop and faint alcohol.  Mouthfeel is fairly warming and features some very fine effervescence overlaying the thin mouthfeel and with combined with a full body.  Not syrupy as one might expect.  Really quite nice.  Seems to fit the season well.

Deep brown body, resembling a dark iced tea.  Thick, puffy dissipating off-white head.  Aroma of caramel and toffee in addition to toast and hints of raisin.  Sharp body of burnt caramels and brown sugar, toast, alcohol, balanced by earthy hops.  Dry and rather thin but with good complexity.
Very enjoyable at 9%. Dark mahogany pour. Roasted malt. molasses, caramel on the nose and tongue. Great mouthfeel. More chocolate at the end.

Bottle on 10/24/06. Clear dark brown with a nicely structurted and well sustained medium tan head leaving a fine lace. Caramel aroma with a hint of roasted nuts, a faint floral essence, and some alcohol showing through. Rich, smooth mouthfeel, medium/full body, and light carbonation. Molasses, burnt sugar, and a spicy hops character give this a bit of sharpness that isnt evident in a Celebrator for instance. Nonetheless, a satisfying Doppelbock that goes down easily.

Bottle pours a dark brown with ruby red highlights and no head.  Chocolate and yeast is primarily the aroma although rather faint at that.  Chocolate, carmel, some dark fruit a little prune and some other dried fruit make up the flavors with a thin amount of alcohol behind it.  They were rather smooth together and could be brought to the forefront a little more.  Finishes with chocolate, sweet and bitter.
Dark reddish brown body with a small tan head. Dark roasted malt aroma with some dry caramel. More dry roasted malt in the flavor with some light caramel.

The 16.9 ounce bottle poured a clear rich mahogany brown beverage with a small off-white fizzy head that was almost mostly diminishing but left some lacing on the glass. The aroma was beautifully complex, much of which I could not differentiate. What I could recognize though were notes of honey, caramel, sweet molasses, and a hint of coffee.   It had a full body with soft carbonation and a smooth, thick texture. The flavor started out sweet with caramel, coffee, dried fruits and roasted grains. The finish was wonderfully long with a comforting alcohol warmth beginning somewhere in the middle and the sweetness lasts throughout.

Nice ruby-brown body with a good ivory, foamy head.  Malty aroma with a slight fruit tang, great for a dopplebock.  Nice taste, smooth tang with an apple/banana accent.  Malty ending with a hint of hops.

Poured a cherry red, like a fire truck ... with a tan foamy head.  Aroma is interesting ... sweet and fruity, but in a thick way.  A thick-bodied beer, too ... syrupy and sweet, but not in a sugary way ... more along the lines of figs, prunes or some other dried tropical fruit.  Excellent beer to warm the soul.

Oh shit....this is good! Aroma of cloves, port, nuts and smoke. Thick dark brown foam which seem to disappear quickly. Dark redbrown colour. Extremely complex flavour, a quitesweet, on the border of yucky. Theres figs, cigar, caramel and lots more. Damn babe! Surprisingly short finish, which is good in this, then you get to drink more..

Dull brown with a murky glow thats heavy in the middle getting slivers of dark gold at the edges and bottom. Huge topping of dark ivory foam thats loose, puffy, fluffy, and thick. Didnt sit for too long before slipping to its always present thick skim and concentrated bubbly center. Lots of great looking inky lacing coats the glass. A beautiful bock to behold!
Aroma is tenderly dark and sweet with semi tanged molasses thats deeply centered in a root beer soaked fruit bread dusted with cooked brown sugar and currants.
Taste is seemingly similar to what the smell leads ya too. A good thing here as this is quite solid in taste, flavor, and body. Smooth and luscious in a thickly coating dark maltyness that brings in a nice molasses tang thats mildly tanged and slow. Nice notes of brown sugar, dark fruity chewy things, caramel, chocolate, and a good portion of length into the finish. By far the best area of the beer. It transcends into its own as it finishes very lengthy with a stretched out dark malty coating and tiny warming.
Nearly perfect for a Doppel in body. Nice easy front with a steady medium body gaining a very complex tone into the finish as the dark malts gain in flavor, body texture, and warmth. Very easy goin down with a great gooey little texture of smoothness. Ahhh, malts, malts, and more malts. Solidly good.
Drinkable and then some. Only a slight hint of warmth after a while begins to settle in as ya go and tends to slow it down. But for a Doppelbock, this is very solid and a showcase of the style.

On tap at Firewaters in Atlantic City...
Appears a deep mahogany toned brown with crimson toned edges when held to the light. A nice, fluffy, light tan head slowly fades out into a rocky film. Tiny speckles of lacing are left around the glass.
Smell is of rich, doughy, roasted nuts, brown sugar, vanilla, maple, molasses, caramel, cocoa, and even a hint of light cherries, along with tropical fruit highlighted by mango.
Taste is of the same wonderful aromas. It definitely lives up to the true German Doppelbocks that many crave in the U.S.
Low carbonation makes this one very smooth but at the same time a tad bit slick along the palate. It starts off biscuity sweet and sort of fades out with a mildly thin slickness that I wish had a bit more backbone for substantiation.
Overall, not bad. Not really on par with Celebrator, IMO, but a good backup to seek out when craving a doppelbock.

Bottle. Pours mahogany with a big cream colored head. The aroma is largely licorice and raisin with a variety of spices. It reminds me somewhat of pie. The flavor has some dark fruit and a lot of woody malt. There is a noticeable date flavor and some toffee in there, too. Some roast comes through in the finish and leaves an aftertaste strangely like coffee icecream with caramel syrup. Pretty good stuff.

looks good nice black with little white head, a full brew. very rich with a great texture, definetly see the port wine in the aroma yet very drinkable. alcohol well hidden by all the other sexy things

Decent dense light brown head of fine bubbles.  Rich and malty aroma.  Very nice.  Sweetness with raisins, grapes and a bit of toffee.  Color is a dark prot brown.  Rich and malty flavor with some roasted grains, maple sweetness, some raisins and more caramel.  Soft mouthfeel.  Finish is rich and creamy.  Lingering malty sweetness.  Hides its alcohol pretty darn well.  A very good dopplebock.

Bottle. Poured dark brown with an average frothy off-white head that mostly diminished with fair lacing. Moderate toated caramel and tart fruit aroma. Medium body with a syrupy texture and soft carbonation. Heavy sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration.

From a 1 pt. 9 oz. euro brown bottle with no bottled/freshness date.

Poured a ruby hued dark brown with a foamy off-white/beige head that settled into a thin, slightly sudsy lacing.

Aromas of figs and port, molasses, caramel toffee swirls, a light sour cherry juiciness, and a very subtle whiffs of alcohol.

Moderate carbonation and a crisp, dryish, velvety smooth light-medium bodied mouthfeel.

Good doppelbock taste, more raisins than figs, a light sour cherry, licorice, bready, a kind of coffee, caramel, toffee candied swirl, a little molasses as well, the alcohol is well masked, but provides a nice warmth in palate, and a dry malty finish.

Just hit the shelves of one of the liquor stores I frequent, great doppelbock drinkability, very quaffable, if you like doppelbocks, then this is a must try.

Pint bottle from porterhouse via trade! - Thanks Kevin! - Pours dark brown wtih a big creamy tan head that stays well and laces the glass in layers.  Aromas of big malts, chocolate, light coffee, molasses, figs, raisins, and an underlying nuttiness..  Taste is again quite malty.  Nice chocolate, nuts, some brown sugar, figs, raisins, a little coffee, and some toffee notes.  Smooth and fluffy palate that I found quite pleasant in the mouth...   This is a wonderful doppel!!  Fantastic!  Rather surprised at the rating number on this one.
Small foamy head, light brown brew. Sweet, fruity, malty aroma. and flavor. Taste like it smells. Good. Aftertaste of cloves, creamy malt. Very warming.

Bottle:  Very nice aroma of figs, toffee, caramel,  chocolate, and raisin.  Pours a transparent mahogany with a moderate beige head that lasts a minute or so.  Lots of malt in the form of caramel, chocolate, molasses, and  toffee.  Moderate fig, raisin, and fruit as well.  After all the malty sweetness is a mildly roasty, lightly smokey, and lightly bitter finish with just the slightest touch of alcohol.  Great mouthfeel.  The full bodied mouthfeel ranks up there with the best of them.  Thick, creamy, and velvety.  My highest rated doppelbock behind 96 Samichlaus.  Im shocked at the average score for this fine brew.

Bottle (500ml).  Clear deep burnt copper with an average tan foamy head.  Solid toasty malt aroma, leafy and hoppy, nice lactic notes, hints of dark fruit and yeast.  Taste follows nicely, dark fruit tartness balances the sweet roast malt nicely, has a tart, lightly bitter, long finish.  Average body, decent carbonation, lightly acidic - very pleasant, well-made beer.

Deep, translucent and ruby brown in color with icy, swirling grey layers and saliva bubbles at the edges (initially, but theres not much in the way of head retention later on.)  Aroma is almost paradise: cocoa butter, nutmeg, parsnip, brown sugared plums and a dynamic chocolate wheat and rye characteristic.  Baked candied apples and a touch of sweetened black currant come in on consecutive sniffs.  Big flavor cannon hums with shae butter, caramelized pecans and chocolate toffee.  Concord and chocolate rye elicit a bright flavor spot, and a buoyant viscosity slide sdown the hatch with accents of coal and buttered rum.  Lightening throat hum is preceded by edible tweed.  Brown sugar is caramelized over figgy pudding, transitioning to a sweet (and graham cracker laden) mince meat pie persona.  Thick, chewy liquid bread with formidable, palatable aptitude.  Chocolate coated caramel chews tell a charming desert tale as it trails into wholesome, cocoa and bread-infatuated bliss.
(Bottle)  Pours a dark brown body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of mlat, licorice, and alcohol.  Flavor of black malts and alcohol.

(06.03.06) On tap at Firkin, Libertyville, IL. Poured clear brown with small off-white head. No discernable carbonation. Slight malt aroma. Medium bodied lager that starts with light malt sweetness and fruity/caramel flavors. Some licorice notes detected. Finished with light malt fade and light bitterness. Very good drinkable lager.
This is the real thing, with roast barley and chocolate malt.  Well balanced, very smooth, good for its style.  Substantive licorice in finish.

Pours a nice very deep mahagony amber with a nice grayish white head. Aroma of light spice like cinnamon and clove with some vegetable DMS, sweet thick caramel malts, but lacks the full rich toasted malts.  Sweet fruity flavor with lots caramel, toffee, plum, raisin, and fig.  Again no thick nutty toasted munich malts like lots of other good doppelbocks, but this is still pretty good.  Unique.

Bottle and served in my NG pint glass: Pours a rich russet hue with a fading fizzy head and no lace. The aroma has notes of caramel, smoke, rye bread, molasses, licorice, and a hint of phenols. The taste is pure sweet dark malt over a layer of over-ripened fig. Additional overtone of smoke and molasses dance across the palate. Not for everyone but malt lovers should enjoy this bier. The best part is that is doesnt come off cloy or over-the-top. Some alcohol warming is noted on the medium-bodied mouth feel. A good brew if I do say so. Just short of greatness but so what because not every bier can be among the top 10 in style. Let hear it for the Benedictine Monks!
Clear, brown beer. Off-white head, fairly lacing. Alcohol notes in the aroma. Flavor has hints of lactic acid.

Bottle at Schnitzelfest at Old Heidelberg.  Poured a clear dark cranberry with a fluffy off-white head.  Aroma of molasses, grapes, and some toffee.  Flavor is dry and complex, with notes of raisins, brown sugar, some grassy hops, and a whiskeyish dryness that betrays the beers strength.  Pretty full bodied but not cloying.  A very nice doppelbock, whose high alcohol helped balance the sweetness and make it quite drinkable.

Bottle pictured poured with dark brown with slight glowing brown edges.  Head is small and quickly escapes.  Aroma is very present.  An alcohol-y malt aroma.  Not overpowering alcohol but present.  Its a light bodied doppelbock, surprising b/c its actually stronger than most.  Flavor is tangy/zingy-malt (if that makes any sense).  Some alcohol burn as well.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Chestnut color with a hint of garnet when held to the light. Smaller light tan head.  THe aroma starts a touch grainy, but then releases some figs and light peat in the aroma. Scents of fresh bread, light alcohol and rich milk caramel as well. Full malty brew, with many subtleties. Light fruitiness start with figs and prunes. Some port qualities. Thicker, in feel, yet quite smooth and not cloying at any point. Mild licorice in the middle that leads to lightly toasted malt and a hint of smoke. I appreciate the depth of the malt in this one. Well developed and rich.

Bottle thanks to Willblake at HW open house. Fairly clear, dark brown color with a small beige head. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, granny smith apples and brown sugar. Flavor of black bread, caramel and dates.

The label on this 500 ml. bottle of Dunkler Doppelbock claimed to be brewed from an historic recipe of 1609 created by the Benedictine Monks.  Since Paulaner Salvator, the first commercially brewed Doppelbock, didnt become available to the public until 1780, this recipe must either go back to the origins of this style as food during Lenten fasting.

Poured out into a flute, this was quite dark in color, and had a two finger head at first.  The head faded quickly to a very thin ring of bubbles around the edge of the glass.  As can be expected with a 9% ABV beer, there was not much lacing.  The aroma was very rich, with the dark Munich style malts allowed to emit a toasty sweet smell.  The taste was also sweet, but not cloying.  The dark fruit ester taste was very dominant here, and was followed shortly by a spicy phenolic kick.  Although they did not use any malted wheat in this recipe, this was somewhat similar to a Weizenbock.  This was quite an easy beer to drink considering all the complexity and strength.  No wonder this Abbey/Brewery has been around since 1330.

Dark brown, opaque, cocoa-toned top, slowly evaporating.

Dark and deeplyrich aroma, caramel notes, molasses, brown sugar, dark fruit...maple, anise, ...sweet, but not too, very well played balance. 

Fully flavored, but mellow in the mouth. Very smooth and drinkable, despite the 9% abv. Slips tasty, tastiness all round the senses. Plums pop up in the flavor department, dates, blackberries...very interesting, this dunkler doppelbock. 

"Brewed according to its historic recipe of 1609, created by the Benedictine Monks." Yea, for that!

A slick and delicious doppel, smooth and very welcome. Yum.

Pours a clear ruby brown with a small head. The aroma is much like dark wheat bread up front followed by figs and dates underneath. The flavor is fairly light, bread crusts, and dried fruits mostly, but theres a salty-like tang in the finish and the alcohol has a bit of a burn.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2006 (500 ml bottle from Downeast Beverage Co.) Pours dark brown with a small soft biege head that recedes to about 1/8". Aroma is kind of sharp alcohol and other sweetness, plus some banana, not what Id expect from a dark doppel. Mouthfeel kind of light, fairly smooth, a little sticky, prickly in finish. Spotty lacing. Flavor is mostly the banana with some brown sugar maltiness way in the back. Some alcohol burn but not bad. Finishes soapy. This was kind of an unexpected mess. Re-rate 9/4/06 on new bottle: No sharp alcohol in aroma. Liked the palate alot better this time. Still quite a bit of banana in aroma and flavor. No soapiness however. Pretty good except for banana - doesnt that just belong in a Belgian?

Nice.  Pours a deep reddish brown with a bubbling tan head.  The aroma is smokey, deep caramel malts with some herbal/grassy hops.  Good flavor, rich with sweet malts, nicely balanced by the herbal hop bitterness... and a touch of smoke and a squeak of the sturdy abv.  Not shabby at all.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL<font size=-1>

"Ended the night of sampling with a bad one. Poured a darker brown with large head which left with no lacing. Aroma was grassy and smoaky. Flavor all bad. grassy dirt, like someone burnt my front yard and put it in a glass. not good"

Well, I was highly disappointed in this one. Poured a dark brown color with a decent initial head that disappeared and didnt lace great. The aroma was smokey and grassy. The flavor was just bad, I thought it was soo much Saaz hops that resulted in not just grassy but dirt type notes. After reading Es review, I think peat smoked is dead on. Peat smoked, grassy flavors with light bready and even nutty notes underneath. The mouthfeel was moderate for the style.

An absolute beauty of a doppelbock, and I see where Stoudts must have got their inspiration for their Anniversary Bock. A nice aroma, if a bit toned down, with notes of melanoidins, a little cocoa, and some spicy hop. Flavor is rounded with smooth caramelized malts, and a minor touch of chocolate. Finish is balanced. The real story here is the balance and mouthfeel. For a 9% malt monster, the beer is perfectly balanced, with a medium body at most. Smooth as all get out. It drinks so incredibly easy. One of the top doppels Ive had.

Bottled. Beer was ckear, dark, brown with a small, frothy, white, mostly diminishing head. The aroma was moderately malty with notes of roasted grain, chocolate, coffee, molasses and nearly caramelized sugar; Hoppy with a light note of her; Yeasty with light notes of cobweb and dough; Traces of oak and vanilla. The flavor was moderately-to-heavily sweet, moderately bitter with a long, lightly acidic, moderately bitter finish. The body was medium, the texture was velvety, the carbonation was lively and there was a light alcoholic warmth in the finish.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is medium to dark brown.

Aroma is moderately malty (bread, nuts, caramel, molasses).

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Straightforward, simple, sweet example.  Malt character in the nose is pleasant, though.

Almost the exact color of Pepsi Cola, decent small head faded rapidly.  Complex aroma, slightly smokey, with additional notes of dark fruit, raisin, coffee, and burnt caramel.  Flavor was very similar to the nose, but the fruit was more forward, with notes of a cherry crisp coming through the other ingredients.  This isnt my style, but I found this beer to be wonderful, true to style and exceptionally well done.

Thanks to goldtwins for brining this one to the tasting.
Small off -white head over a clear brown body.
Moderate malt aroma some fruits.
Malty caramel, but some alcohol adds roughness to the palate. Some tartness detracted from the flavor and a bit thinner body than I like them.

Poured a clear brown color with a ruby tint and small beige head.  Sweet fruity malt aroma with notes of grapes and apples.  The flavor was sweet and malty with a good amount of dark fruits.  Semi-dry and pretty warming.  Light bitterness on the finish.  Medium to full bodied.

Another really drinkable Doppel but by no means a Celebrator.  Beautiful black body with a small tan head that vanishes wihout leaving lace.  Sweet chocolate nose.  Taste is chocolate and dark roasted malt with a good bitter finish.

Glowing brown amber hue in the light with a bubbled gray head. Slight roast and enjoyable chocolate nose with a crisp note. Flavor is banana peel, oh yeah, banana peel. Caramel chocolate finish that tastes like caramelo candy bars. A yeasty plum flavor to this too. This is good.
Ap- 4 ar-7 tas-7 pal-3 ov-15

(500ml bottle, thanks Goldtwins) Crystal clear copper body with off-white head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, chocolate.  Taste is moderately sweet, chocolate, caramel.  Some alcohol burn in the finish.  Creamy medium-full body.  Hops?  We dont need no stinkin hops!
Dark ruby.  Moderately sweet aroma, some dark fruits, cloves?   grainy notes as well.  Some decent dark malt complexity,  full-bodied, but despite all of this somehow less than the sum of its parts.

The body is very dark with ruby highlights. The head is light tan colored and small bubbled. The aroma reminded me of smoked ham along with some pears and pink bubblegum. Strange smelling beer. The taste had some light honey with pineapple notes. There is also a hint of tobacco and smoke. Finishes sweet with the tropical fruit notes. An interesting beer, but needs a little more roasted character to keep me happy.

Draft at Drafting Room, Exton, and bottle, from Super Saver.  This rating is of the draft.  It poured dark brown/ruby edged, with a 1-finger off-white head.  The aroma was heavy malt, chocoff, nuts, molasses, slight rauch, cabernet, and BS (brown sugar).  The taste was heavily malty, with a big, rich, brown sugary cacao molasses, nuts, and some hops.  Velvety palate.  Like corn flakes dipped in dark chocolate, brown sugar, and nuts, then placed over a campfire for 30 seconds and then quickly dipped in red wine.  Yummy!

Beer tasting sampler at <a href=http://ratebeer.com/Place/illinois/orland-par Orland Park. Deep malt smell, properly dark brown in appearance. My first impression is of strng alcohol, but its not harsh; helped in fact by a very mellow roast and a fruity nose. Even manages a somewhat creamy texture.

Pours a transparent dark mahogany brown with an airy, thick tan head.  Sweet, peppery dark wheaty aroma has lots of complexity with some raisins and German yeasty notes.  Nice sweet dark caramel malty flavor some a touch of earthy, spicy noble hoppy bitterness and a drier bittersweet alcoholic finish.  I needed a water chaser with this one.  Its almost too over the top, but has some good characteristics otherwise.

Deep, reddish brown appearance with a small, off-white head and little lacing.  Fantastic earthy aroma with lush, dark fruits, spices and molassas.  Full bodied, moderately carbonated, mildly hopped mouthfeel.  Roasted malts highlight the taste, with notes of dark fruit, dried fruit, toffee, spices and a modest amount of smokiness.  Long lasting, slightly sweet finish.

(bottle) Clear and dark ruby mahogany colour with a medium sized frothy and diminishing tanned head. Sweet roastmalty nose with caramel and bread-crust of German Schwarzbrot. Sweet and slightly bitter flavour, medium to full bodied, smooth carbonated mouthfeel. Roasted malty taste with caramel; finishes quite bitter for a Doppelbock and slightly hoppy. Roasty aftertaste.with liquorice and anise. Well-rounded Doppelbock.

Bottled version. Clearly states that its 9% ABV and a rep for B. United said that all American bottled versions would be 9%. Aroma is rich and full of dates and raisins with hints of wood smoke and some toffee. Flavor is full of roasted malt and light cherry. An absolutely excellent example of an extra strong doppelbock.
Bottle. Dark brown in colour with a medium head. Nice maltyness and also nice sweetness. Hints of chocolate anf figs. Pretty good.

Now this beer was damn fine.  The aroma had ginger and cinnamon and some carmel with roasted malt.  The flavor was bursting with cinnamon and giner and nutmeg spices along with light chocolate touches and nutty flavors mixed with a big carmel feel.  Very dark brown with light tan head that stays around for a bit.  There were just a lot of flavors in this and very very well balanced.  Glad I got to have it on tap.

Bottle. My bottle lists the alcohol as 9.0% ABV. Pours a deep mahogany. Small tan head. Nose is fruity and malty with light caramel, and a touch of dark alcohol. Taste is sweet and malty. Lots of fruit notes (figs and raisins), light choco notes, soft toasty notes, and caramel. Body is creamy and smooth. Medium bodied. Finishes much sweeter than expected with more alcohol notes, dark fruits, caramel, light coffee, and soft toasty notes. Nice!

Pours a flat chocolate color. Reddish highlights on the top and bottom. Very complex in flavor. As it reached a warmer temp. the flavors exploded. Clove spices with a tart aftertaste that in constantly present. Very mellow for 9.0%abv. 1 is enough, anymore is an overkill in flavor..The label confused the hell outta me, what am i drinking?!

Draught, 9% version.  Clear ruby brown with a fluffy, persisten off-white head.  Sweet, malty aroma of toffee, raisins, light, earthy hops, sweet apples, light alcohol, sweet brown sugar, some light esters (WHA?) and a hint of toasted, grainy bread.  The body is smooth with light carbonation and moderate weight in the tongue.  The flavors are real nice with loads of sweet malt, estery fruit, warm alcohol and toasted bread.  Maybe a touch of cocoa as well.  The finish is long, sweet and warm.  The Maproom claims this is a different version than the normal variety (7%) and Id like to try the two side by side.  This one is awesome, even if it has some fruit esters in there as well.

Dark brown in color, chocolate, figs, and other fruits along with a strong sweetness fill the nose.  Taste is overly full of alcohol at the start and more rounded and warming as well as rich and robust towards the end.  A very nice example of a strong dopplebock.  I like this one.

Pours dark brown with reddish hues and a fully receding off-white head. Aroma is typical bock lager yeast and with a few extra roasties thrown in. Taste of sweet caramelized bread, plums, nuts, and brown sugar. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with lively carbonation. Enjoyable, but not a paint-by-numbers doppelbock.
Quite good.  Fairly complex.  This is very hoppy for a bock.  Heavy body, and there are light fruit flavors under the standard sweet bock aroma.  Dark brown and a sizeable head.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2008 Very dark brown/ruby. Large, foamy, tan head settles to a thin layer. Aroma of bready yeast, cloves, dark fruits, green plants, incense, light toastiness, and some spicy-ness. Same flavors with a touch of alcohol in the finish. Full, balanced, chewy palate somehow maintains an amazing drinkability. One of the best doppelbocks Ive had.
50 cl bottle. No yeast at the bottom. Reddish dark amber colour with a small head. Very malty aroma with notes of caramel. Also malty flavour that ends up smooth and nice.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2006 [Draft @ Grand Cru] Poured an amber color with a small, tan head that left no lacing on the glass.  Aroma of peat smoke, caramel, and nuts.  Taste of much of the same, light roasted malt, rum soaked raisins, and light alcohol.

Bolttled. Enjoyed during the terror of a Sunn O)) concert:
Bown appearnce with brown head. Very sweet and sirupy touch. Warming alcoholic finish. A good doppel.

Bottled.
Clear brown coloured with a medium sized off white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, bread and caramel.
Sweet flavour of malts, caramel and bread with notes of hops.
Dry fnish.

Bottle from Onlyfinebeer. Brown with a fine head. Sweet, caramel like aromas. Flavour is somewhat one dimensional, sweet malts, caramel and a touch of fruit. Standard stuff for the style, nice though.

Small, offwhite head over dark red-brown clear body. Sweet smell of toffeelike malts. Big, sweet taste of malty, caramelly sweetness, slowly growing bitter towards the end. Good, but doesnt really stand out.

Bottle. Chestnut brown with a large creamy off-white head (because I poured it that way). Nice complex aroma; roasted malts, caramel, some dark fruits, some chocolate. Taste doesnt disappoint, sweet malts with caramel, well hidden alcohol. Full bodied, low to moderate carbonation. One of the better doppelbocks.

Bottle: Reddish-black coloured, small brownish head; complex (as usual) nose: roasted malts, coffee, fruits (nuts),  vinous too; sweet-malty taste, becoming step by step drier towards the long bitter-fruity finish; quite well hidden alcohol; a well rounded, a bit sticky, well drinkable and deceptive brew.......

(Bottle 50 cl) Red, very red - actually more red than brown. Very smal head - close to absent. Very roasted - almost burned - notes. Sweetish malt and a huge body-feel. Very classical Doppelbock. 180505

Bottled. Deep reddish copper colour, small bubbly brown head, which disappears quickly. Caramel and alcohol strikes nose at first, with some breadish hints at a closer look. Sweet caramellish flavour with weak hints of roasted malt. Weak alcoholic flavour is present too, but fits the flavour very good. A bit roasted and sweet fruity aftertaste.
Brown with small ligth brown head. Notes of sweetness and malt in the aroma. Taste is with malt and notes of caramel

Darkbrown coloured beer. Sweet caramelly aroma. Very sweet doppelbock, lacking a great finish. Buttery sweetness comes through more and more towards the end. OK brew but certainly not the best Doppelbock.

(on bottle) Clear, dark oakcolored. A nose of dark grapes, alcohol and dark chocolates. Semi-bitter/sour mouth and a, for this style, light finish with brown sugar-, plume- and dadenotes. The alcohol is felt freal fast and it´s a fairly easyly drunken beer, dangerous.
Bottle. Reddish brown coloured. Malty aroma. Sweet and malty flavour with roasty  and bready notes. Well balanced and full bodied.
Clear brown reddish with a disappearing off-white head. Malty, caramelly and nutty aroma with bready notes. Malty and caramelly in the flavor. Rather sticky and artificial and not very impressive.
Bottle. Red-brown colour with a medium baige head. Sweet light roasted malty aroma and a sweet malty light bitter taste. Medium to full body and a sweet bitter finish.

Bottle
Chestnut colour, creamy amber head.
Sweet toffee and roasted aroma.
Caramel flavor, nice balance, marzipan aftertaste - otherwise unevebnfull. Medium to full body, slightly sticky mouthfeel. Pleasant.
Thanks Dortmunder.
A clear red-brown beer with a small brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of alcohol and roasted bread. The flavor is very sweet with notes of caramel and roasted bread.

Caramelly nose, clear dark brown color, low foamy head. Toasted malt with some blueberry notes. Some butter too - like a blueberry pancake? Sugary sweetness and a slight vegetable taste. Towards the end dry and quick woody dryness. Thinner than youd expect. Overall OK, but not overwhelming.
Thanks a lot dortmunder! Nice red color, small layer of a head, soft carbonation. Roasted malt also butterscotch nose. Sweet malt taste, some berries -  currant taste.  Butterscotch aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2005 2005, tap at Cafe Ledig Erf: Nice balance, bit more spicy, which gives the beer more body. 
Original: Dark color, medium head. Aroma of roasted malt, some caramel. Heavy roasted malty taste, bit sweet. Not too complex, but full bodied.
Aroma of malts, caramel and some coffee and spices. Brown coloured with a beige, lasting head. Taste is sweet, malty caramel and coffee in it. Quite smooth and decent brewed.
Bottle. Never really my favourite style, but this was pretty easy gpoing, less sweet and sticky than most doppelbocks. Some caramel, dough and light soy flavours. It wasnt bad.
Butterscotch and malts aroma. Redish brown color, small beige head, good lace. Bit on the sweet side, butterscotch, smooth, silky, clean and straighforward as we are used to with German brewers.
very sweet maltyness in the nose, with some plum and hints of alcohol. Dark reddish colour with a small fast dissappearing head. Malty flavor with some sweetness from dark fruit. Plate is thin.
dark ruby color, malty, nice anis taste. very warming, light bodied, excellent beer.

Dark brown body with reddish glints and fair off-white creamy head. Aroma is nicely complex: various notes of spices, malt, fruits, and brown sugar. Strong malty taste with sweet hints and nice warming effect. Long sour finish. Very good winter beer.

Bottled: Clear amber coloured. Brownish dense head. Huge at the beginning, but diminished quite quickly. Malt, fruit and some chocolate notes in the aroma. Flavour of fruit, liqourice and alcahol. Alcahol is quite well hidden. Ends on a malty notes with some alcahol at the bottom.  Quite good one, but not in the same ballgame as Andechs and Ayinger.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2005 Bottle.  Chocolate/coffee aroma.  Reddish-brown clear color - small head.  Sweet chocolate malt flavor with a very nice coffee finish - not as astringent as Ive found in many doppelbocks.   An excellent beer for the style but may not be stronger enough for fans of the style.

(Bottle) Garnet body, clear, cream coloured thick head. Nose gives malt aroma, warm bread, caramel. Taste is sweet, malty, with a flavor of a milk cream dessert. Oily texture, full to medium body, "sticky" mouthfeel.

Bottle. Rated in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany. Tan head, carbonated, transparent, no lacing, and a reddish brown hue. Malty, and caramel and some alcohol notes in the aroma. Flavor was malty and vinuous. Tingly and somewhat of a thin mouthfeel. Light bodied Dopplebock,

Dark red color with hints of brown, off-white head lasted long. Strongly sweet and fruity aroma with notes of roasted syrupy and alcohol. Flavor is very ordinary: starts with mild roasted side, ends with overly sweet and vinous aftertaste, which lasts long. 7.0% ABV is covered pretty much, comes up slightly as vinous aftertaste. For me, mild aroma was slight disappointment, flavor differs some other doppelbocks, but not in bad way.

The DM & Hotstuffs European Honeymoon trip beer number 64. This bottled brew from the Ettaler Monastery in Oberammergau Germany poured a large sized head of finely sized off-white colored mostly diminishing bubbles that left behind a softly carbonated transparent dark brown colored body.  The aroma contained notes of strong caramel malt and dark brown malts.  The mouth feel was initially smooth vinous malty and finished with a lingering vinous aftertaste.  The flavor contained strong notes of malt and caramel malts.

A top class German beer. Deep garnet/brown colour with a modest head. Big, nutty malt aroma, with toffee too and a touch of malt. Berry fruit and burnt malt flavour, with some licorice and a smoky edge. Not too sweet. Rich, but not that full bodied. Dry finish. Drinks very easily. 500ml bottle from beersofeurope.co.uk. BBE 30 September 2004.
Dark brown colour, with a off-white head. Very malty taste and aroma. Nuts, toffee, caramel, molasses in the taste. Not as sweet as most Doppelbocks, but more bitter, especially in the finish.
A beautiful mahogany, very smooth doppelbock that boasts a very complex aroma with figs, fruitcake, dark malt, molasses, port, and a whiff of smoke on the palate.

Superb red-brown, clear beer; thick luxurious creamy head. Bready nose, truly great and appetising. Malts - in a superior way, and caramel. Sweetish & roasted taste, like mulled beer, caramelised in a short, hot way. Retronasal there are some good German hops. Just a bit thin mouthfeel, certainly for a Doppelbock. All the same, if this beer isn't nourishing, nothing is. This is a great, because dangeroulsy drinkable Doppelbock. Love it.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2004 Bottle
Dark reddish-brown colour and thin tanned head. Sweet fruity malt aroma, slightly alcoholic. Strong sweet and malty taste, like stronger version of Kozel Cerny. Quick alcoholic finish. (7/4/7/3/15 3.6)
Re-rated, bottled (BB 09/2004)
Dark red, off-white small head. Burned malt and fruits in the nose. Sweet, roasted, delicious balanced palate. Sweetness in aftertaste. (7/4/7/4/15 3.7)

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2004 Deep, dark ruby color, with slightly tanned, medium head. Very malty, slightly sweet and roasted, trappist-like, even slightly port-wineous aroma with plums and rye bread. Sweet and rye-malty flavor with caramel and a bitter, chalky finish. Sugary-sticky, lasting aftertaste. Extremely full-bodied, oily, slicky, perfectly balanced palate. ABV is excellently hidden. Liquid food - yummy! Be sure to drink it slightly warmed up (14-16C).
Pours brown with a hint of ruby. Has a thick tan diminishing head. Initial taste was sweet with a bit of soy sauce and worcestershire sauce. Has a mild roast malt aroma. A nice beer.
Dark brown, thick beige head, few lace. Bitter and coffee-like nose. Full bodied, roasty and caramel-like. Sweet, bitter flavor.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2006 Bottle: deep dark brown color, poor head. Malty raisinny aroma. Full bodied, almost thick. Sweet and malty flavor. Tropical fruit, caramel and some chichorei. Alcohol clearly noticed. Malty, bitter aftertaste. Firm high quality doppelbock.
Tap: Café Morshuis Albergen. Sweet, malty flavor with roasted malt and some bitter chocolate. Mango. Soft but persistant prickly mouthfeel. Not a sign of alcohol. Very likeable.
A tap sample tasted in feb 06 had a mint and anis character.

Bottled. 
Chestnut brown with creamyhead. heavily roasty. Sweet and full bodied. Malty with thick, chewy mouthfeel. Notes of toffee. Bitter grassy finish.

(500 ml bottle). Another traditional Kloster Dunkler Doppelbock, ABV is 7%. Colour is dark brown to ruby, good light tan head. Fine aroma of oak, coffee and cigar box. Heavily roasted to burnt malty flavour, alcohol shines through. Roast bitterness in the aftertaste. Not as good as the Weltenburger Kloster Asam, but still good.

Dark and dangerously drinkable.A heavy burnt slightly nutty taste with a very full body.
Highly recommended but in moderation!
Lovely dark doppebock with a pleasantly burned, dark taste and a full body. Packs QUITE an alcoholic kick!
